dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a chartered plane flying from Miami to Newark Airport. JACK is the captain. His copilot PAUL is seated beside him. In the passenger cabin, a female gymnastics team is celebrating a hard-won, glorious victory over the Miami team. They are singing, dancing in the aisles and drinking champagne. In the rear of the cabin, there are three regular pass- engers: a teenager, his mother, and a man who appears to be a BUSINESSMAN. The plane is flying over the coastline. The partition between the cockpit and the passenger cabin is open. Jack is very excited. He can't stop turning around to look at the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paul)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! I can't believe my eyes! Look at these women! Will you look at the gorgeous calves on them?! I'm telling you, give me an athlete any day... Oh God! Look at that redhead over there, and look at that one! Christ, I hadn't noticed her. (miming a heart attack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, I've just fallen madly in love with the most beautiful woman in the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally uninterested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though about to keel over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde over there, she's too gorgeous for words. Just look at those eyes, look at those shoulders and the way she moves. I'm in love. Here, take over, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets up and Paul takes his place at the controls. Jack makes his way up the aisle, through the girls who are blocking the way, to the object of his affections. She is sitting in one of the aisle seats and singing her head off. Jack leans over and whispers, quickly and intensely, to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.   I'm the captain of this plane.   May I ask your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, my name is Jane.    Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Jane, I've seen many beautiful women in my life but I swear to you, I've never, ever met a woman as exquisite as you are. Jack kneels down before her, and the Girl looks at him, amused. He takes her hand and places it over his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane, can you feel my heart? It's pounding. This is horrible, I think I'm gonna faint. Listen: I'm madly in love with you, I'm single and here's my phone number. He hands her his business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm putting my fate in your hands. If you don't call me, you'll make me the most miserable man on earth. This is no line and I'm not trying to get you into bed. This is something completely different. I love you Jane and if you call me I'll be the happiest man in the entire universe -- this is 'love at first sight.' Out of all these beautiful women I noticed only you, and... The Girl laughs as Jack goes on. Meanwhile, the Busi- nessman who was seated in the rear of the plane has gotten up and walked over to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. (to Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Jack and I live in a fabulous apartment in Manhattan overlooking the park and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're the pilot, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm the pilot... (to Jane) ... I'm not even asking for your phone number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there a pilot whose name is Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Yeah, the copilot -- he's up front... The Businessman disappears in the direction of the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving it all up to you, Jane, but if you do give me your phone number, then Jane, then... The Businessman has reached the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone) Are you Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning around nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Are you Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He hands Paul a man's purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have it. We've got problems. Too much heat. Too

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: risky. We think the cops are on to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda ya mean us?   You mean me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean shut up and listen. Two guys will be waiting for you in a black T-Bird, expecting the dope. Just ignore them. It'll be delivered to you on Sunday and picked up the following Thursday, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I won't be home, I'll be in the air for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem. Make arrangements, a deal's a deal. Got it!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. Jack returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting with excitement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got her phone number!   She gave me her phone number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some magnificent view, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful -- Life is wonderful! The Businessman goes back to his seat and Jack grabs hold of the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your captain speaking. In honor of your victory, in honor of your beauty, and in honor of Jane, the most beautiful gymnast I have ever met. I'm going to give you a little demonstration of aviation gymnastics -- reserved only for the most important guest, hip, hip... Everyone shouts "HOORAY!" except for Paul and the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Businessman, who remain grim. Jack dips the plane very low over the water and skims the cliffs along the coast. It is a beautiful, impressive stunt. There are gleeful shouts in the cabin among the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is saying an emotional goodbye to Jane as she leaves with her teammates. Jane finds it all very funny, but Jack looks totally wretched seeing her go. Jack and Paul walk toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, what a woman! Paul is nervous, glancing uneasily from car to car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna share a cab? Paul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure! A black Ford pulls up in front of them and its driver looks at Paul who immediately turns his back on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so beautiful! I've never been so in love before. Can you believe she gave me her phone number... Oh, Christ -- where is it?... Oh, no, don't tell me I lost it... It's a matter of life and death... Oh here it is -- thank God! All the while    Jack has been rambling on, a beige car on the other    side of the street has slowed down. Paul notices it.     In the beige car, a narcotics agent, GRAT is behind the    wheel with one of his colleagues sitting beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're slowing down.    Take a picture. The colleague snaps a picture of everyone who happens to be standing near the black Ford, including Jack and Paul. The black Ford pulls out. The beige car follows it. Paul observes all this out of the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I need a favor, I got

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a little problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... Hey, look, will you -- look at that sparkling beauty. A very beautiful woman is coming down the walkway with cart overflowing with luggage. One of them falls off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I mean, it's like... There's this little package...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll never make it with all that luggage she's got. I gotta give her a hand. Look at the colors in her hair! Christ, I've never seen a woman like her before... He's about to walk off when Paul grabs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, listen, can I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can, no problem... Listen, I gotta go now, I'm gonna see if she'll share a cab with me.  You take the shuttle, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I gotta explain to you about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over to my place tonight. We're having a huge party. Come around 9, okay? See ya later. Jack races toward the woman and begins to help her with the fallen luggage. We see him talking to her and we can hear a little of what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As exquisite as you are... I think I'm gonna faint. He kneels, takes her hand and puts it over his heart. The young woman is flabbergasted. A lonely-looking Paul hails the shuttle bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, stylishly decorated apartment in Manhattan. A tremendous living room. A party's going on. Very LOUD JAZZ is PLAYING. The lights are dim. There are about 30 guests. Lots of young pretty women. Gourmet buffet. People are sitting on couches talking, others are eating, drinking or dancing. In a dimly-lit corner, Jack is kneeling before a girl sitting in an armchair. She is laughing as she listens to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering passionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no line and I'm not trying to get you into bed. This is something completely different. This is 'love at first sight.' Oh, I'm so happy... Let me go get you a glass of champagne. I'll be right back. Jack gets up and goes over to the buffet. As soon as he's out of the girl's line of sight, he starts running toward the other end of the apartment. On the way he passes MICHAEL, who's deeply engrossed in a vehement conversation about modern art with a girl called SOPHIA. They're fighting like cats and dogs but seem to be enjoy- ing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that's art, are you really saying that's art? Well then you explain why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes back to prehistoric man. They had comic strips on their walls, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering in Michael's ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a hard time.    I'm working on two at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brunette in the armchair in the living room -- her name's Rosalie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clementine -- she's waiting for me in the den. He moves away towards the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sophia) Wait one second for me, I'll be right back. Michael walks off in the direction of Rosalie. Paul is wandering among the guests, trying to find Jack, he sees PETER who is talking with another young woman, NICOLE. Peter is nodding, idly looking around, com- pletely uninterested in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys have a beautiful place here. But the rent must be a killer. Peter isn't paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it a killer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh,    the rent... yeah, it's high but    split between the three of us    it isn't that bad, as long as    we don't eat. Nicole laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Peter, I'm looking for Jack, have you seen him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi, Paul, how are you doing? Yeah, sure, I'll take you to Jack. (to Nicole) Excuse me for a minute. They move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lifesaver, I've been trying to get away from that woman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for 20 minutes. That sonofabitch Carl is moving in on my Natalie. Gotta go... bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- What about Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a hurry) He's around somewhere.     Check under all the couches. Paul walks off in Jack's direction. We STAY WITH Peter, who reaches Natalie. She is talking with a very styl- ishly-dressed, tall, young man, CARL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Natalie, I've been looking for you all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All night? I just saw you deep in conversation with Nicole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep? Hell no, we were just talking shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on Peter, we all know what a ladies' man you are. PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, me? Jack's the ladies' man, not me. You're the only lady I'm after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) So tell me, how's your project coming along? I heard you're not ready yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've still got two weeks left before the semi-finals. We'll be ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been ready for three days now. We're gonna kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their project is really incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?   You've seen it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling broadly at Carl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's top secret but he's been telling me about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a bad mood) Ours is incredible too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever get it finished. Paul comes up to Jack, who is kneeling before Clementine, whispering passionate sweet nothings in her ear. It appears he's gotten beyond the "This is love at first sight" stage. He's getting down to the nitty-gritty now. Clementine is thrilled. Paul taps Jack on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, can I talk to you for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Paul, yeah sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clementine) ... Please darling, don't move... I'll be right back, okay? I'll bring us back some champagne... He disappears with Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lifesaver, Paul. I thought I'd never get away. Rosalie's waiting for me in the living room. Isn't she terrific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?   Rosalie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clementine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, for sure, I dunno. Listen, can you do me a favor? With some difficulty, Paul follows Jack as he picks his way through the people dancing, heading in Rosalie's direction.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah... What kind of favor? Damn, I've got to get her a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Listen, I've got a little problem. I'm having a valuable package delivered to me on Sunday, but I'm not going to be home. I've got to do the Hawaii-Tahiti-Australia route, so can I have the package delivered here instead?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (filling a glass with champagne) Yeah, sure, of course. (he stops, thinking) No, wait, I'm leaving for South America tomorrow. I'll be gone for three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it's okay. Peter and Michael will be here. They'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Will you be sure to tell them about it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Absolutely.   Don't worry about a thing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It'll be delivered Sunday and picked up next Thursday, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Delivered Sunday picked up Thursday. Got it. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is a very delicate matter, Jack. It's very important they don't tell anybody about this package. It could be very... uh, embarrassing for me, you know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sure. You got it.    I'll see you later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is about to rejoin Rosalie.     Paul grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to anyone at all.    Tell them that, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sure, not to anyone at all... Look, I'm sorry Paul, but I gotta get back to Rosalie. Now go have a good time. I'll take care of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye and thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it. Paul leaves. Jack finally reaches the armchair where Rosalie is sitting. He stops short, obviously disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.   Too late. Michael is sitting next to Rosalie, right next to her. They get up to dance. As he passes Jack, Michael smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All's fair, old buddy... Jack watches a moment, then breaks into a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my darling, oh my darling, oh my darling Clementine. Jack whirls around and heads back towards Clementine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are leaving. Commotion in the hall, people are saying goodbye to Peter and Michael. Natalie is about to walk out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie, why don't you stay for a nightcap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've gotta get up early...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Natalie) Do you care to share a cab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, thanks -- that's really nice of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling triumphantly; to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a forced smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Carl... I'll call you Sunday, Natalie. She has already left.   The door closes on the last of th departing guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you struck out again with Natalie, huh? That Carl is a real smooth operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an asshole! (mimicking Carl) 'I heard you're not ready yet.' 'We're gonna kick your ass.' Well, we may be behind schedule, but we're still going to beat that sonofabitch and maybe I haven't scored with Natalie yet, but neither has he. She's not an easy lay, that's what I like about her. You know what they say: it ain't over till it's over. Peter and Michael go into the living room. Peter is picking up glasses. Michael is emptying ashtrays into the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't do so well either -- I blew it with Rosalie. I don't even know how...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Rosalie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That beauty I managed to swipe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Jack. I was about to ask her to stay the night when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your old friend Sophia appeared and got you involved in a thrilling conversation about modern art, and meanwhile Rosalie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, all you want to do is steal Jack's girl friends. You don't give a shit about the women themselves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. It's just that Sophia drives me crazy. She knows all the right buttons to push to make me mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going into the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, it was a great party, everyone had a good time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in the living room, shouting to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific... time. He, too, leaves the living room and runs into Jack, who has his arm around Clementine's waist as he heads toward his bedroom with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen Peter is straightening up. Michael joins him, dumping the ashes. Peter begins washing the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jack?    Did he leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's cuddling up with a blonde named Clementine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Clementine. I saw him doing his famous routine with Christie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is Clementine, the one with the tits this big...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christie's got tits that big, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he was with Christie at the beginning of the evening -- after that he was with Rosalie and then with Clementine. And since I stole Rosalie away from him... Are you following this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. Jack enters the kitchen in very high spirits, singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice work if you can get it, and you can get it if you try... Any scotch left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, here, I just put it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I can't give you guys a hand, but I've got something cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were leaving at dawn for South America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, the night's still young!... It's gonna be a lively one. I'm gonna make us a little snack. He makes up a tray with sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who is it anyway -- Christie or Clementine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine.    Beautiful, enchanting Maxine. Peter and Michael look at one another surprised, mouthing silently, "Maxine?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Michael -- how'd it go with Rosalie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, things were going great until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your old friend Sophia appeared and dragged you into a thrilling conversation about modern art and in the meantime Rosalie took off with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno -- lucky guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't give a damn anyway, I have 24 drawings to hand in to my editor three days from now and I gotta work all night anyway... So it was all for the best. But you better not leave that Maxine's phone number lying around because when I'm done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll leave you her phone number on the hall table. If she's really terrific I'll put a big 'X' next to it. 'Bye, guys -- love ya. I won't wake you tomorrow morning. See you in three weeks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Maxine noiselessly exit the   apartment. Jack is wearing his pilot's uniform. Maxine    pushes the button for the elevator. Jack sneaks back    into the apartment and leaves a note on the hall table   that says: "Maxine 227-2013." Next to the number Jack    has put a big "X."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Maxine exchange a brief kiss and go their separate ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is in the cockpit with his copilot, RON. The ENGINES are REVVING. Jack is checking gauges. He looks out the window idly and sees: The crew of another plane walking across the tarmac. Paul is one of the crew. Paul sees Jack and begins to gesture wildly, but his voice is drowned out by the noise of the ENGINES. Just seeing Paul is enough to remind Jack about his package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! I forgot to tell them about the package! (to Ron)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta make a quick phone call. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, there'll be plenty of girls where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon, I've really got to make a phone call! What do you think I'm going to do, pick up one of the New Jersey delegates to the I.B.M. convention? Jack walks back towards the phone. As he walks we see that the plane is filled with ugly, boring businessmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the architecture firm of which Peter is one of three partners. The whole staff, about 15 people in all, is gathered around a large model, the project for a big amusement park. They all seem worried about something. JERRY, one of Peter's partners, seems particularly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The model's not finished, the blueprints are a mess and you may as well forget the specs, they're a disaster! I know we're talented. I know we're good. Then why is it we can never get organized? Why is it we're always behind schedule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jerry, architects since Leonardo have always been behind schedule. It's a tradition, for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's sake.   Why break with tradition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this is the chance of a lifetime for our company, and there happens to be a deadline. There are millions of dollars at stake here. And our main competition had their project in three days ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but word around town is their project's a piece of shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it's a piece of shit, but it's a ready piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just going to have to buckle down, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn right we are. Starting now, everybody works around the clock! Everybody! We have two weeks to be ready for the semi- final selection. And we will be ready. And we will win. You want to know why we'll win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're gonna cheat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go bribe the judges!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think this is a joking matter, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jerry... A SECRETARY enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an urgent call for you, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jack -- he says it's 'super important...' Peter picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... yeah... listen, make it quick, I'm in a meeting here... yeah, a package... okay... someone'll drop it off Sunday and pick it up Thursday... No problem ... yeah... we'll put it aside, okay... no, no, we won't tell anybody about it... Is that it?... Right, we won't tell anyone... Hey -- love 'n' kisses to the Brazilian girls, vaya con dios, old buddy. Peter hangs up, laughing.    Jerry gives him a dirty look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, dressed in casual clothes, knocks on the door of Michael's room, and peeks in. Michael is asleep fully clothed on his bed. His drawing table is strewn with papers, overflowing ashtrays and empty coffee cups. The lamp is still on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out for bagels -- how many you want, three or four?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening one eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.M. or P.M.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.M.    C'mon, up 'n' at 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up 'n' at 'em yourself, asshole -- I just went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you finish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I didn't get anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then... nap time's over. Back to work. So how many bagels, three or four?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six, six! He buries his head under the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter opens the front door, he stumbles over an object, looks down; at his feet he sees a wicker basket lined with pretty pink-and-white checked gingham. In the basket a tiny baby lies fast asleep, her head gently resting on a lace pillow. Peter looks at this object in amazement. There is an envelope pinned to the basket with the words, "FOR JACK" written on it. Peter picks up the letter -- he opens it and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding! Abruptly he turns and races back to Michael's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael!    Michael!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still groggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your ass out here and see what's on the doorstep. (mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has gotta be somebody's idea of a joke! They run to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a basket with a baby in it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No shit. (reads Michael the letter) 'Dearest Jack, here is the fruit of our love. Take good care of her. I have to go to Europe and Japan for six months, her name is Mary. Good luck, Love, Sylvia.'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are we going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Give it back to her mother, that's what.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But it says she went to Europe.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, we'll see about that, d'you have her phone number?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Whose phone number?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: The girl's... Sylvia's...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why the hell would I have her number? I've never even heard of this chick!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You mean you don't know who she is?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No way. If I had to keep track of all Jack's girlfriends, I'd have to be a full-time secretary.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, what are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hey, look, she's waking up... Hey, look, she's crying...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh no, this can't be happening! She's not gonna start to cry now?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, now she's really crying!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What's her problem?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Maybe she's hungry?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, what are we s'posed to do?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Feed her, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Soft stuff... I guess.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (exploding) Oh no, I swear to God this is unreal! Can you believe that bastard Jack?! 'A little package,' he tells me on the phone, 'just put it aside till Thursday.' Put it aside -- can you believe him!?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Really?   Jack said that?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah and he also said 'don't tell anyone about it -- anyone at all.'

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, so he told you about this?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he told me a package would be coming today, but he didn't say it'd be this!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (very angrily) Boy, he's got a helluva nerve!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just listen to the racket she's making! What are we s'posed to do?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (brilliant idea) Let's call Jack's mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lives in Miami for Christsake. She can't stop the baby crying from Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just to ask her advice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he said not to tell anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is an emergency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No way! You know what a pain that woman is -- she'll be on the next plane here to move in with us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should call my mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please -- leave the mothers out of this, okay?! It's only four days. We should be able to handle that, besides you know the rule around here: it's fine to have a woman over once in a while, but... Michael finishes the sentence in unison with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... never for more than one night at a time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that includes mothers! Peter steps over the basket and heads towards the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the store to buy some baby food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do while you're gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick her up and hold her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic-stricken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean, pick her up? I've never held a baby -- I'll drop her! Peter is already gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the store and rushes right over to a store CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What aisle's baby food on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down there by the meat section. Peter heads for it purposefully. When he    gets to the right aisle, he stops short, taken aback:    a vast range of products extends before him. He starts    examining th baby food jars and cans of formulas, going   from one to the next, not knowing where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is still in the hall holding Mary very clumsily in his arms. He is anxious. He realizes she's soaked. This disgusts him. He holds her at arm's length; she squirms. He goes and gets a towel from the bathroom, spreads it out on the living room couch and lays the baby down on it. MARY SCREAMS -- she much prefers Michael's arms to the couch. A panicky Michael picks her up again, grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, don't cry like that... I'll hold you, I'll hold you. He tries rather unsuccessfully to wrap the towel around the child. Obviously Michael is very put off by the smell coming from Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is talking with a Safeway CLERK, a woman in her 50's, who is tall and heavy, somewhat gruff and masculine in appearance, and wearing slacks and a smock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the best brand?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Depends on what your pediatrician recommends.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh right, the pediatrician... But which one sells the most?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: (pointing to a can) This kind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, so this is the best kind?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: It's the cheapest.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Then it's the worst kind?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: They're all good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (pointing to another can) Oh, okay, then I can take this kind.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: It's got iron in it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh.   Is that good or bad?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: It's very good.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, why don't they all have iron in them?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Some babies are allergic to iron.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (pointing to yet another can) Oh, okay, well I'll take this kind then.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: That kind doesn't have any milk in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, there's milk with no milk in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some babies are allergic to milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the stuff that no babies are allergic to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soy formula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, I'll take the soy formula. He takes a can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one's Advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really?   What's Advance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old's your baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Peter tries to estimate Mary's size)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... about this old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY is SCREAMING in Michael's arms as he walks her up and down the whole apartment. Now there are three towels wrapped around her. Michael is exasperated. He angrily sings her a lullaby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock-a-bye baby on the tree top...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop crying now; c'mon, stop... quit it, will you?... When the wind blows, the cradle will rock... What is that jerk doing? Milking the cows or something?... When the bough breaks the cradle will fall... MARY only SCREAMS LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Peter is surrounded by three women arguing: The Store Clerk standing with her arms crossed and haughtily looking down on everyone; an efficient, practical sort of young woman (WOMAN #1); and another thin, pale woman whose baby is lying in a baby carrier in her shopping cart and who seems very nervous (WOMAN #2).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she have any teeth yet or not? That would give us a clue as to how old she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly disagree- ing; to Woman #1)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandson's only five months old and he already has two teeth. But my daughter didn't have a single one at seven months -- so, y'know, how many teeth they have... doesn't mean a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't those friends of yours tell you what formula they usually give the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually they had to leave unexpectedly. They had to catch a plane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she teething?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teething?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she drool? Does she cry all night long? Does she chew on her fists? Does she put everything into her mouth? She acts out her words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she can't talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't those friends of yours tell you how old she was?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (as Woman #2 is starting to get on his nerves) I told you they had to leave unexpectedly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Or else you could weigh her; that would tell you how old she is.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: See, my five-month-old grandson weighs more than my neighbor's grandson and he's nine months old. So, y'know, how much they weigh... doesn't mean a thing.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So what about me? What should I buy?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Didn't they even tell you the pediatrician's name?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (still calm) No.   They didn't.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You sure have weird friends.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You have no idea how weird.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Or else her hair. Does she have lots of hair?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: My grandson, y'know, he has so much hair you can make a ponytail with it! And I know some kids who are totally bald at a year- and-a-half. So, y'know, how much hair they have... doesn't mean a thing...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Gee, he's really something, your grandson -- is he good at math too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter starts to pick cans off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, ladies, thanks for all the advice. But I think I'll just take one of each. To be on the safe side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget -- if the baby's less than three months old, you have to be sure to sterilize the bottles. Peter stops and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bottles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what?     This must be a kidnapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is rapidly    pacing up and down the apartment, vigorously rocking    Mary. As soon as he sits down anywhere to rest,    MARY SCREAMS, so Michael pops back up and begins the    marathon all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary had a little lamb, little lamb, little lamb, if that jerk isn't back in three seconds I swear I'll throw her down the garbage chute... Mary had a little lamb, little lamb... The DOORBELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's about goddamn time! He hurries towards the door, grabs the knob and throws it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been? He stops. Before him stands the apartment MANAGER, Mrs. Razzolini, a squat little woman with a moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Hi, Mrs. Razzolini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This package came for you... Oh! What a cute little baby! Is it yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not me, I mean she's not mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so it's Peter's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's Jack's, I mean it's not Jack's, it's... someone loaned it to us, I mean someone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's the little girl's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, what a pwetty wittle name, Mary! I didn't know you had a baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I have to put her to bed now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to put her to bed?    Where's Mary's mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's... she's not here.   She'll be back soon. Michael starts to close the door.    She pushes it back open and holds out the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh here, this just came for you. They just dropped it off. Can I hold her for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, like, y'see... she doesn't like to be held by strangers... The apartment Manager has already given Michael the package and grabbed Mary. She covers her with kisses. Mary smiles. Michael absent-mindedly looks at the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loves to be held by strangers! Hey, she's soaking wet hmm, no I think it's number 2. Want me to give you a hand changing her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, don't worry, I'm used to it. (faking a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so long, Mrs. Razzolini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Mary, I'll come back to visit. Mrs. Razzolini regretfully hands the baby back. No sooner is MARY back in Michael's arms than she SCREAMS her head off. He closes the door; his smile instantly fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a leech! And that other idiot isn't back yet! He throws the package onto an armchair in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you love to be held by strangers, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the baby food aisle there are now five women arguing. Peter, his arms still laden with cans, looks uncomfort- able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy doesn't even know how old his baby is and you don't find that strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy asked for advice,   I'm giving him advice, Okay?    If you're so paranoid, why don't you   run home and chain your kid to   his crib?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I think someone should call the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops, the cops -- I bet you call the cops every time your cat pisses on the carpet. Peter slips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter comes in with bags in his arms. Michael, holding the baby, dashes toward him, extremely pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell were you doing? You've been gone for hours! This damn kid's been crying the whole time. I've got a lot better things to do with my time! You're a real pain in the ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flabbergasted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how dare you speak to me like that! You've never spoken to me like that before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell took   you so long? What'd you do, go    out for breakfast or something?    I didn't even have time for a cup   of coffee, for chrissakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please cut it out for a second, huh? I didn't have any coffee either, it took me forever at the goddamn Safeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, here -- take the kid, I've got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddaya mean, take the kid? I can't hold her and make her bottle at the same time. And why should I be the one to hold her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause, it's your problem.    You found this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole, I'm the one who found

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her because I'm the one who was gonna get you some bagels for your breakfast, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, there she goes again!      We gotta feed her something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well you just don't feed a baby. First you gotta look and see if she has any teeth or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To figure out how old she is so we know what to feed her, that's why. Peter attempts to look into Mary's mouth but she squirms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you look on top or bottom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try feeling with your finger. Peter slides his finger over Mary's gums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't feel anything -- I'll give her the stuff for newborns and hope she's not allergic to it. Peter starts off toward the kitchen, Michael follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then we'll    have to  see if she's allergic    to iron,  to soy or to milk --    you can't  imagine how much stuff    they can  be allergic to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's soaking wet -- did you buy any diapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures. I'll take care of this, it'll save time. He sticks Mary in Peter's arms, right on top of the bags, and storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael rushes in and stops short in front of the moun- tains of diaper boxes that he starts examining in bewil- derment. Finally, he approaches the Store Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss, could you tell me which diapers are the most absorbent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would suggest the ones that say 'ultra-absorbent.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but which are better:    20-35 pounds or 12-24 pounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends how much your baby weighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh right, how much she weighs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threateningly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't happen to have a friend who came in here a little while ago, would you? Michael grabs just any box of diapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you're talking about! He's no friend of mine. Michael takes off very, very quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, in Peter's arms, is devouring her bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, my slacks! Goddamn her, she took a crap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael have laid Mary down on the couch, taking care to place several towels between her bottom and the immaculate velvet. Mary is squirming, laughing, feeling great. They have already gone through half a box of cotton in their attempts to clean up the crap. But it's still all over, on their hands, on the baby's feet and legs, on the towels, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold her.   Hold her, goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hold her. This kid's out of control here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just gimme the cotton. Michael lets go of Mary's feet and she sticks them back in the crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for chrissake, don't just let go of her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get the cotton yourself if you don't want me to let go of her! Peter grabs a huge wad of cotton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the towels off -- They're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the couch'll get dirty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but she keeps getting it all over herself. Man, this shit is sticky!... We need cleaning fluid or something to get it off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout after-shave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?! Waste our Saint Laurent on babyshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's just put the diaper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on and the hell with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Michael hands him a diaper.        Peter tries to figure how it goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These tape things -- do they go on the front or the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to know...? Peter tries to slide the diaper under Mary's backside but she squirms and kicks it off with her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold her under her arms -- I'm gonna try it this way. Michael holds Mary under    her armpits.     Peter tries the diaper on her. It's     hard. What's     more, it wou seem that Michael didn't    buy the right    size -- The diaper comes all the way    up to Mary's    chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of lousy stinking diapers did you get? They're way too big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're too big -- They're ultra-absorbent. That's all. The more absorbent the better. Peter has more or less managed to adjust the diaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do these tape things work? Hold her for chrissakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My arms are getting tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.     I got it. He tapes the diaper closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it.     I didn't make it tight enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tapes the other side:   the diaper gapes and sags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not working... What about laying her down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead... No, not on the towels, they're all covered with crap... Michael lays Mary down right on the couch. Peter vigor- ously undoes the tape, and the whole PLASTIC lining RIPS apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What the hell is this friggin' mess? Oh, man, this is unbelievable! To think, they bombard us day and night with their goddamn TV commercials! And will you look at this junk? This stuff is pure shit -- You tape it closed, it sags, you undo the tape: bingo -- the whole goddamn thing falls apart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking another diaper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whaddya expect, if you pull on it like an ape, it's gonna rip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, will you give me a break, will you please? Peter takes the torn diaper off. MARY utters a TINY CRY and pees copiously all over the velvet couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Now she's pissing. Look at the couch. The sneaky little bitch was just waiting for me to get the diaper off, then whammo... Mary gives them a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to like my furniture. I'm going out to get some real diapers.  You can clean the couch up in the meantime. He exits, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is cleaning the couch with Mary in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is wearing only a diaper.   Peter wraps her in one of his sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is throwing a heap of used cotton and dirty diapers into the garbage can. He's rather disgusted by them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is cutting apart a plastic bag and lining the bottom of the basket with it as a protective sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is washing out a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is rocking the basket by its handles to put Mary to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is washing Mary's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to reach Jack Collins, he's one of your pilots... No, I don't know exactly where he is, but he was supposed to be flying the Miami-Caracas-Rio route... The guy who proposed to you?... Oh, did he?... Well, congratulations. Please... listen to me... you must contact him and tell him he's got to call home immediately. Okay? It's an emergency, a family problem... No, don't worry, he's not married to someone else. It's another kind of family

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: problem... Of course he still loves you. But he's been really busy lately. So anyway, please try to get in touch with him, it's real important... I can count on you then?... Good. Thanks. Goodbye!... Right, see you at the wedding. Peter hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Peter are finally drinking a cup of coffee at the kitchen table. In silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael are standing beside the basket.   MARY is SCREAMING; they are bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's allergic to something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe she's hungry again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is making the bottle, Michael is holding MARY, who is CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it snappy, will ya, she's famished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in Peter's arms voraciously sucking her bottle. He watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is washing out the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is about to lay Mary down in her bed.    He puts hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hand on her backside, then picks her up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, she's soaking wet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is rinsing out Peter's sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the couch, Peter is struggling with the diapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael has set the basket on a serving cart.    He pushe it back and forth until MARY STOPS CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is sleeping like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Peter are in the doorway.    A stormy argumen is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no you're not, you're not gonna leave me alone with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you -- I have a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rotten bastard -- do you see me going out on any dates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's with Natalie -- I've been after her for months already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what! If you leave me alone with this kid, I swear I'll pack up and be outta here by morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real drag, y'know? Tonight was gonna be my big night! Now I bet it's gonna be Carl's big night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, violently slamming the door behind him. Michael sits back down, grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is making a phone call.   He has Mary in his arms. He's in a foul mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Natalie? It's Peter. Listen, I'm really screwed. Jerry just called and we've run into a snag with the blueprints for the competition, it's an emergency. I've gotta go over to the office right away, I think it's gonna be an all-nighter... Of course I didn't know about this yesterday -- he just called me. Mary reaches out and begins to jab the buttons on the phone. Peter pulls her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello?... No, I'm not trying to hang up on you. We're having some problems with the phone, that's all... No, Natalie, there's no one else here! You're the only woman I... I swear I'm not lying to you... What? You're going to call Carl? (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go ahead, call him if you want. I don't give a shit... Of course I'm not jealous. What makes you think I'm jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael are silently eating sandwiches at a corner of the kitchen table. Peter is fuming. Michael glances at him out of the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, completely zonked, is changing Mary as best he can. Peter sits, waiting, on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is rocking the basket, as if in a trance.   Michael

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: goes back to sleep on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is talking on the phone.   He has Mary in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, hi, it's Peter. Listen, I've run into some problems, I can't make it today... (holding the receiver at arm's length from his ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hey, take it easy, will you... I'm sick. Seriously ill. I'm burning up... The doctor had to come, I've gotta stay in bed till Friday. (shouting to drown out Jerry shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey, I'll work round the clock all weekend long... I swear, Jerry, I am not lying to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, wearing a coat, enters carrying packages that he puts down in the living room, now transformed into a nursery. A makeshift changing table, rubber wash basin, baby clothes, baby lotion, talcum powder, soap and baby shampoo, etc. are all over the place. He drops all his purchases on the floor, sits down on the couch and picks up a book, in which he's instantly absorbed: we see from the cover that it's a book on children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is lying on his bed now surrounded by dozens of baby-care books. Many of which are open. He's reading them with great passion, and making notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is sitting on the floor surrounded by his drawings. Mary is lying next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, Mr. Oxman, but I've run into a few problems, I won't be able to bring you the drawings tomorrow morning as I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: promised. In fact, it won't be until the day after tomorrow at the soonest. Michael sees Mary kick over a bottle of india ink over his drawings. He winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On second thought, Mr. Oxman... uh, better make that the end of next week. (shouting on the other end)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't get upset, Mr. Oxman. I'll do everything possible to get them to you sooner... You have my word... I apologize again, Mr. Oxman... Thank you again, Mr. Oxman. Goodb... (an audible click)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Oxman? Hello, Mr. Oxman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is a total mess. A harrassed Peter, lying on the floor, dreamily watches Mary who is lying on her tummy in a sheet, playing with a SQUEAKY RUBBER GIRAFFE. They look at each other, as sober as judges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael are asleep in their bathrobes on the living room couches. Peter has a child care book over his face. MARY, in her basket, wakes up and utters a FEW LITTLE NOISES. The two men jump up and go over to her basket like robots. Mary looks at them and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is giving her night feeding. Mary is falling asleep in his arms; the nipple falls out of her mouth, which goes on sucking anyway. Michael is falling asleep, too, his head lolling over to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is back to normal, spic 'n' span. They've gotten rid of all the baby paraphernalia.   The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: basket is on one of the couches.     Mary is asleep. On the basket are warm clothes for outdoors, a bonnet and a coat, a full bottle, cans of formula, toilet articles, and a pile of diapers. Seated on the couches facing each other, Peter and Michael are waiting for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say what time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he said was Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific! -- We could rot here till eight o'clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm prepared to rot here till midnight if I have to, as long as we get rid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack really could have called. He has to have gotten our message by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when he does call, I'm gonna let him have it! That sonofabitch is on the beaches of Brazil proposing to the whole goddamn world. And we're here living in hell! He's gonna get his ass on the next plane back here. Vacation's over, Jack-baby, you better believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right! (beat softer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost time for her bottle, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street two men drive by on a motorcycle looking at the numbers on the apartment buildings. They stop a few yards from the entrance to Peter, Michael and Jack's building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are being followed by the beige Chevy that pulls ahead of them and parks just beyond them. In this car we recognize Graton sitting with a partner. The two men, who look like young tough guys (punks), get off their motorcycle and disappear into the lobby of the building. Graton gets out of his car    and heads for the building. He glances into the lobby,    then goes in. He watches th elevator floor indicator,    notes the floor it stops on, then calmly returns to his    car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael are still sitting on the living room couches. The DOORBELL RINGS. Michael springs up and runs to open the door. Peter follows him. On the    doorstep stand the TWO PUNKS. One of them is short    and speaks with a heavy Brooklyn accent. The other,    tall, thin and creepy-looking, stands behind hi buddy    and doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Collins live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came for the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Package? Oh that's cute, referring to her as a package! Anyway, you can tell Sylvia she's a lousy stinking bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Sylvia! You can tell her she's got a hell of a nerve dumping her problems into our laps!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems? Did you guys have trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to know if we had trouble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what it's been like around here for the past four days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could have at least given us a phone number or the name of someone to contact...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) I don't get it. Didn't they tell you we were gonna be here today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure they told us! So what? That doesn't make the last four days any less hellish than they were!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, they're here now, that's all that matters! Peter turns and walks toward the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next bottle's in 45 minutes. I made it already. It's in the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottle?   Whadda ya mean, bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour after her bottle, she starts yawning. Put her to bed right away or it's pure hell for the next three hours, at least that's what we've noticed. Peter has returned with the basket. The Punks look at the baby, their eyes wide with disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?   A baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) No, it's a very short teenager. Of course it's a baby! Now listen carefully: I'm giving you a can of the milk she's been getting. She loves it, and more importantly,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she's not allergic to it. I even put a can of the same brand in here for you, but in powdered form, understand? Punk #1 hears "powder" and catches on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! I get it!      Powdered milk! Very clever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right... real clever... Okay, here. She's all yours. Good luck. He hands them the basket.    Punk #1 grabs the handles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I got it. You can take her out now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take what out?     I'm not taking anything out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I don't get it! We take the basket and the milk, that's all. We ain't gonna take the... what's inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda ya mean, what's inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take it all, man!    It's a package deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what are we s'posed to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know? You take it where they told you to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'mean, I take it to the connection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever you want to call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's the plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet that's the plan! We're not keeping her one more second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, if that's the plan... He passes the basket to Punk #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Here, hold this. Okay, so long! They start to leave, pressing the elevator button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly a little worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... listen... maybe you could leave us the address or the phone number just in case. So we can find out how she's doing? The Punks exchange a puzzled glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sure, the address. (feebly searching his pockets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, I don't have it on me... But I'll call you. Okay, so long! PETER & MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long! The elevator has arrived.    The Punks quickly slip insid it with the basket. Michael closes the door. Peter plops down in the armchair by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah, relief at last!    Good riddance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it! Now maybe I can get some work done. He disappears in the direction of his room. Peter is sitting    on something hard. He pulls it out fr under him, it's    a package. He looks at it, casually reading: "Care     of Jack Collins." He tosses it to the side. Suddenly,     it dawns on him. He leaps up, grabs the package and    runs into Michael's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the package)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a package, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this package delivered to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why? Peter raises his voice, exasperated by Michael's calm attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the hell did this package arrive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you quit shouting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming even louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did this fucking package fucking arrive, Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Oh yeah, Sunday -- Mrs. Razzolini brought it up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the package those guys came for, not the baby, you asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole yourself!... Oh shit! Peter nods and begins to bark orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out the window and see if you see them, I'm gonna try to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: catch up with them... Michael runs to the window. Peter runs like a madman through the apartment out the front door. He presses the button for the elevator. It's in use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamit! He opens the door leading to the stairs and races down them, holding on to the bannister. He flies, overwhelmed by anxiety. Suddenly he trips, loses his balance and makes a spectacular crash landing. The package gets a bit crushed, and little individual packets of white powde spill out of it. Peter stares at them in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? He picks up a few packets and examines them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, no... dope!    That's all we need! He starts to tremble  with fear. He picks the packets up as fast as he can and  hastily puts them back into what's left of the package;  then shoves it all into his pocket and continues racing  down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punk #1 is attempting to strap the basket onto the motorcycle with a bungie cord. Punk #2 watches him coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be better off taking the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to ride the subway with a hundred grand in uncut dope, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we can't ride around carrying this baby basket.    We'll get stopped by the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So go ahead, take the subway and stop bothering me. I'm going to hook this onto the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll never hold, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately going at the hook and the basket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn hook! Christ, what a stupid idea hiding the shit with this kid. It's ridiculous! Peter comes rushing out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huffing and puffing) Oh, thank God, you're still here! There's been a terrible mistake. That wasn't the package you were s'posed to take. It was another one. I have it right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What other package?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the basket back and give you the other package, here. No mistake. Peter takes the package from his pocket and is about to grab the basket. Punk #1 pushes him back violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't takin' nothin' back, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm tellin you it was a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low but very aggressive tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tryin' to double-cross us or something? Beat it before I get pissed, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic-stricken, in an equally low tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm telling you, I've got your package right here. There's been a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mistake my ass! Now get outa here, man, or I'm gonna stick this right in your gut. He discreetly reveals a switchblade knife he's carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Punk #2) Start the bike. Punk #2 is about to get on the motorcycle.   Peter stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm telling you, I've got the real package in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Punk #1) Watch it, the cops! Peter quickly puts back the package in his pocket. A patrol car comes up next to them, right beside the car in which Graton is sitting, taking in every bit of the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his partner) Terrific! I bet these morons screw up everything. One of the COPS gets out of his car and comes over to the Punks and Peter. Peter is scared stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) If you called the cops on us, pal, you're a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what's that doing on the back of the bike? No one answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't by any chance be intending to drive with a baby basket on your motorcycle, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Officer. We'd never do something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why did you strap it on in the first place if you had no intention of driving with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it wouldn't fall off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny. As he speaks, Peter undoes the bungie cord from around the basket and takes it off the motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, Officer, they weren't gonna drive off with it -- They were just watching it for me while I was doing a quick errand. (to the Punks) Thanks, guys. Punk #1 gives him a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's see some identification, everybody. The punks exchange a glance.   Suddenly Punk #1 shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! They take off running in different directions. Cop #1 charges after Punk #1 and yells to his partner who's still in the car:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the guy with the basket! Cop #2 leaps out of the car, gun in hand. Peter stiffens with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze! All right, asshole, let's see some I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urbanely) Listen, Officer, let's stay calm now. I haven't the slightest intention of running. I am not a criminal. I'm an architect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your I.D., let's see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, Officer, but I don't have any identification on me. I just came down with my baby to run a quick errand. I haven't committed any crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's go, in the car. I'm taking you down to the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon, that's impossible -- you see I have a baby. I have to give her a bottle in fifteen minutes, I can't go anywhere. I live right in this building -- let me go up to my apartment and I'll get you my license immediately... You can even come with me if you like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, lead the way. They disappear inside the building. Peter is carrying the basket in his left hand; his right hand is clenched on the horrible package hidden in his pocket. Just then Cop #1 comes running back, empty-handed. Graton gets out of his car and comes up to Cop #1, show- ing him his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
