dialogues.text: (angry) Inspector Graton, Narcotics. It just so happens I was tailing those two guys and now because of you clowns I lost them, probably forever. Thanks a lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could we know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. Listen, your partner went in here with the guy and the baby. He lives up on the tenth floor. I can't go in because if he sees me, my cover is blown. So could you please try not to lose this one, okay? He's someone who's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gotta be watched very closely. I've called for backup and it's on its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open, Peter and Cop #2 exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (key in hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. Please come in... can I get you a cup of coffee or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.   I'll just wait out here. Peter enters the apartment and calmly crosses through the house, carrying the basket. As soon as he's out of the cop's sight, he starts running like a madman down the corridor. He runs into Michael who was just coming to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's happening? What were those cops doing... Peter shuts him up, grabs him roughly under the arm and leads him into his room, closing the door behind them. Peter speaks softly but he's totally freaking out, he can hardly breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael... Michael... we're in deep trouble. The package... The package...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?   What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a cop on the doorstep... He didn't see you... He mustn't see you... We're in deep trouble, Michael...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The package  they came for wasn't the baby, it  was dope, drugs, a shitload of  dope! We were stopped by some cops  down on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But did the cops see the dope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's right here. He takes out the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get twenty years if the cops find this on us! Climb down the fire escape and hide it... anywhere! Michael takes the package, opens the window and starts to climb out it when Peter stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, whatever you do,   don't lose the goddamn dope, we   gotta be able to return it to   those dealers or we're dead. Those    guys are serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. He starts down the fire escape, then stops and turns back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, I put some water up to boil for her bottle. Michael disappears. Peter picks up Mary, grabs his  wal- let and leaves the room. When he gets to the hall,  he discovers that Cop #1 has joined Cop #2, to whom he is whispering something. Peter holds his license out  for them to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask you to remain in the apartment. The narcotics squad will be arriving any moment now. They want to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narcotics squad? What do they want with me? I don't even use aspirin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is buying a pair of scissors, glue and a roll of Scotch tape. Then he buys a box of large diapers -- he chooses the ones that come in a box. Michael leaves the supermarket, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is sitting on a bench facing the grass, with his back to us, he seems quite busy. As we CLOSE IN, we discover that he has opened the box of diapers and that he's holding one of them; its plastic has been carefully cut out with scissors. Casually, glancing right and left, he takes the individ- ual packets of white powder out of his pocket and shoves them into a little plastic bag from the supermarket. Then he carefully tapes the bag so it's well-sealed and flattened out, and he inserts it into the diaper, be- tween the plastic and the absorbent fabric. Next, the diaper is taped up, folded back up and put back in the box, neatly packed between the other ones. Michael closes the box again and glues it together so it looks as if it's never been opened. He throws all the other stuff away in a trash can and grabs hold of his brand-new box of diapers. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael comes into the living room with his box of diapers and a bag of groceries. In addition to the two cops there are now THREE NARCOTIC AGENTS who are interrogating Peter. He is holding Mary. The basket is on an armchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Officers... What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Michael, it's nothing serious, just a little misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you give her the 5:30 bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just gave it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you change her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll do it. Michael puts down his bag of groceries, takes Mary from Peter and disappears with the box of diapers. In his room, he lays Mary down on his bed and starts undressing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my roommate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising an eyebrow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't see. There are three of us sharing this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, three, huh? A regular 'mirage a trois'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 'menage'... and it's not. We all have lots of girlfriends, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, so what's your friend do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a cartoonist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the other guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-hah... Now that's interesting... (to his colleague)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Get me those photographs, the ones taken at Newark Airport. Agent #1 looks in his attache case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does this friend of yours ever fly to South America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Never.   Only North America. The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you object if I answered it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, go right ahead.    I've got nothing to hide. Agent #1 picks up the phone and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a collect call    from a Jack Collins in La Paz,    Bolivia. That wouldn't happen to    be your pilot friend, would it?     The one who never goes to South    America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is him. Agent #1 hands him the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, yes, operator, I accept the charges. Agent #1 gestures to Agent #3 to take a look around the apartment. Agent #3 slips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind very much if I listened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, go right ahead. Agent #1 picks up the other telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jack? Fine, yeah. How're you? Yeah, he's fine, too. Yeah, we left a message for you, right... No, it was nothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: special, it was just, I mean... to see how you were doing and all ... No, no emergency. Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said everything's fine! The what?... I don't know what you're talking about... Oh yeah, the package! Yeah, yeah, it got here ... and was picked up, uh-huh. Hey! Why didn't you call sooner? Huh? 'Cause what?... Oh, you're onto something hot -- well, aren't you the lucky one!... So when are you getting married?... Forget it, I was just kidding... Well, everything's fine up here. So have a good time. See you in a couple of weeks. 'Bye. Peter hangs up.   So does Agent #1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's interesting. So you wanna tell me about this package and the hot something-or-other your friend lucked onto... in La Paz... Bolivia... South America? Peter sits down, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is lying on Michael's bed. He has just finished putting a regular diaper on her. Then Michael looks for the tampered-with diaper in the box. He finds it, checks that it is well-sealed, and places it under Mary's bottom. Just then Agent #3 appears in the doorway. Michael calmly finishes putting the dope-filled diaper on the baby on top of the other one. MARY is COOING. Every- thing appears normal. However, a trained eye might be very surprised by the enormous thickness of the diaper covering the young lady's backside. But a narcotics agent is not necessarily the most qualified person to notice something odd like this. Agent #3 silently observes Michael, who gives him a big smile as he slips on Mary's pajama bottoms. Michael picks Mary up and for the first time talks to her in the kind of silly babytalk used by adoring parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey, honeybunch, it's time to go beddy-bye now... We're gonna take a nice long nappy-wappy... He goes back to the living room, followed by Agent #3. Agent #1 is in the process of showing Peter a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize anyone in this picture? Peter looks: it's the photo of Jack and Paul that was taken at the beginning of the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   This is Jack Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?   Now that's interesting. Michael has laid Mary down for a nap in her basket, observed by the five cops. He now sits down, cheerful and bubbling over with enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! Can I get you something to drink? Agent #1 totally ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who's the baby belong to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jack's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why are you two taking care of her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because her mother's in Europe for six months, and since Jack had to be away for two weeks, I took my vacation to take care of her, I love kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Peter and I just love kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's interesting. Well, we'll be seeing each other again soon, in fact very soon. In the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: meantime, I'd appreciate it if you didn't leave New York in the next few days. All the cops head for the door. Michael accompanies them, putting on a very urbane act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back anytime, gentlemen. You're always welcome here. We have no particular plans to leave New York in the near future, so don't worry about us now. 'Bye now. Once the cops are gone, Michael races back to the living room. Peter has collapsed into his armchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone) Christ, what a mess! They'll be on our tails around the clock! How the hell are we gonna get rid of the goddamn dope?! By the way, where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also speaking in a low tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool, don't worry, I got it stashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? Michael points to Mary's bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way it's close at hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I diapered the dope on her right in front of the cop and he never noticed a thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the cops we were taking care of her. You realize we're now stuck with the kid till Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes back. There ain't nobody coming to pick her up, and I have to go back to the office today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You're not gonna stick me with this kid! Tell them you need a maternity leave, tell them anything, but we've got to go 50-50 on this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's not all -- we haven't heard from the punks yet either!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hidden within a parked car, three men are keeping a close watch on the entrance to Peter, Michael and Jack's build- ing. The two uniformed cops emerge, get in their car, and pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone; things are heating up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, you heard right: I'm not coming in to work for two weeks... No, I can't explain why... (in a louder tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Because I can't, that's all!... NO, this has nothing to do with chasing ass! Jerry... Jerry! Will you stop screaming for a minute and listen? I'm in trouble, you understand? Deep trouble... I know... I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Goddammit, Jerry, of course winning the competition is important to me! The firm's my whole life if you must know. No, no, please -- don't send anyone over here... Don't you come either. No, Jerry... Okay, listen, I'll be there in a half-hour, but I can't stay long. No! Don't come here! I'll be right over. He hangs up.   Michael enters the room, with his coat on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go over to    Mr. Oxman's -- he just called and    he's freaking out. He says if I     don't bring some cartoons over    now, the deal's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but don't worry about it, I'll be back before it's time for her next bottle. She's asleep now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific, just terrific! Jerry just called: I have to go to the office right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, call him back. Tell him you'll come later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way. I can't, he's suicidal. Why don't you call Oxman and tell him you'll be there in a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Oxman is leaving in an hour. If I don't meet him before then, I blow my 15,000 dollar contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, I can't take this anymore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, maybe we could pawn her off on Mrs. Razzolini, just for a couple of hours -- she's crazy about her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea!    Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael get out of the elevator on Mrs. Razzolini's floor. They each are holding one of the handles on the basket. They are walking quickly. Suddenly Michael stops Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- I hear someone... I'll go see... Peter waits with the basket.   Michael tiptoes to the corner of the corridor. At the very end of the corridor, on Mrs. Razzolini's doorstep, he sees the three narcotics Agents talking with Mrs. Razzolini. We can hear snippets of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I brought a package up to them... I think it was last Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are these people like? What kind of lifestyle do they have? Michael hastily returns to Peter, still on tiptoes. He leads him back to the elevator and pushes the elevator button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Just as I thought -- the goddamn cops are grilling Mrs. Razzolini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! We sure as hell can't hand her the baby with an ass full of dope... right in front of the narcs! The elevator has arrived meanwhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking down) What should we do? I really gotta go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, she's just had her bottle. She's sleeping like a log. Let's just leave her in the apartment. What can possibly happen to her? She's as regular as clockwork. She won't wake up till 8:30 and we'll easily be back by then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're right, we won't be long. They rush into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men, slumped in their car, are watching the door of the apartment building. The three narcotics Agents emerge from the building and walk away. A short time goes by. Peter and Michael emerge from the building and quickly walk away. The three men get out of their car, cross the street and enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter comes out of the elevator, key in hand. He's about to put it in the lock on the door, but stops short -- the door is already open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael?   Michael, are you here? No answer. Peter pushes the door open. The sight that greets his eyes is very dismaying. It looks like a tornado has hit the house. Everything's on the floor, it's all been smashed, it's all been ripped apart. Gone is the beauti- ful apartment that had been so lovingly decorated. In its place, utter devastation and shambles. Peter stands there speechless for a moment, then an awful thought crosses his mind. He runs like crazy into his room -- the basket's not there. Stepping over the debris and all the things strewn over the floor, he rushes into the living room, then into Michael's room. The basket's nowhere to be seen. Peter falls apart; without even realizing it, he's moan- ing and muttering distractedly. He runs into Jack's room, into the kitchen, into the bathroom. The basket is nowhere to be seen. Peter runs all over, back and forth ten times in all the rooms. Tears are flowing from his eyes. Suddenly, he hears FAINT CRIES.   They're coming from the back bathroom. Peter rushes to   it, practically ripping the door from its hinges. There   on the toilet is the basket, and on it there's a note  written in big messy printing which says: "NEXT TIME   WE TAKE HER." Mary looks at Peter and smiles; she seems in great shape. A distraught Peter picks her up, hugs her tightly and kisses her all over as he takes her into his room. Just then, Michael appears in the corridor, silent and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: overwhelmed. He comes to the door to Peter's    room and looks at him. Peter, mortified to have been    caught kissing Mary, hastily distances himself from   her, hold- ing her at arm's length. He puts her down on    his bed and exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The debris has been shoved up against the walls. Peter and Michael, in their pajamas and dead tired, are slumped over the table. Peter is giving Mary her bottle. Michael is looking at Mary as though he were seeing her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is in bed, completely out of it. Michael is changing Mary very carefully. He puts one diaper on her, then the second one, full of dope. He lays Mary down in her basket, then places the basket on the bed, nestled between the wall and Peter's body. Michael, holding the soiled diaper, silently goes out. Once he's alone, Peter leans over the basket. Mary and he stare at each other intently and seriously. Peter switches off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. Michael, asleep on his mattress on the    floor in the middle of his wrecked bedroom, emerges    from sleep and glances at his clock: it's 6:10 AM.      He staggers to t front door and opens it. The door is     being held toget with a string. Agents #1, #2, and #3 are at the door, with four other cops backing them up. Mrs. Razzolini is standing behind them and staring, wide- eyed, a look of horror on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, officers. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out a piece of paper to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing  the gentleman, waving  away the paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you,  officer. Go ahead, we have nothing  to hide. Hello, Mrs. Razzolini! Mrs. Razzolini turns her back on him and hurries away. The cops enter the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to excuse the mess... We had a few friends over last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the devastation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Well, if I were you I'd get myself some new friends! Peter comes in, in his bathrobe, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you guys looking for, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably the same things your friends were looking for last night! Didn't Mrs. Razzolini bring you a package last Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the chocolate Easter bunnies? We ate them already. He starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, you have no idea how many packages we've been getting lately. It's hard to keep track of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can help. (to his colleagues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get to work! All the cops enter the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is in bed, with the basket beside him. A narcotics AGENT is rummaging through his scattered belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I look in your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure. Try not to make a mess. Peter gets up, takes the basket off the bed and keeps it in his hands. The Agent searches the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look in the basket, if you don't mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest. He picks up Mary with her huge diaper.   The Agent searches the whole basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, sorry about this... He goes out.   Peter, undaunted, pats Mary's big behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's obviously been a mistake. As far as you're concerned this investigation is closed. We apologize again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't mention it! It was a pleasure having you here! I hope you'll find what you're looking for very soon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking straight at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do we. Michael closes the door and races into the living room where he discovers Peter putting on his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? He said there'd been a mistake and they weren't going to bother us anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, it's a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?    Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just said that to put us off guard. They saw the condition this apartment's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know the punks were here looking for the dope and that they probably didn't find it. So that means we've still got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he said the investigation was closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's just see how closed it is. I'll go downstairs. You watch out the window and see if I'm being tailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is peeking out at the street from the window above. Peter comes out of the building and turns left, walking very quickly. Suddenly, Peter stops, turns     around and retraces his steps. We can clearly see a      man, who was walking abo six yards behind Peter on the     opposite side of the street, also turn around and     retrace his steps. It is Graton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?   Was I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one guy for sure! A redhead, kind of young, disguised sort of like a college student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. They're going to be watching us around the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we going to get the dope back to the punks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the feeling they'll come to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to be very careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is walking on the street carrying two bags of groceries. Suddenly, a guy walks up to him and elbows him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! Doin' a little shopping, huh? How's your place -- not too much damage, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you guys want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want the dope. Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we want to give it to you. But the cops are tailing us nonstop. Matter of fact, there's one right behind us now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem, man. Figure out a way to shake 'em. Either we safely get the dope tomorrow, or you, your friend and the kid'll get this. (he quickly stabs the grocery bags three times)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call you tonight. He runs off, disappearing into the darkness. From the slit-open grocery bag milk flows out onto the sidewalk. Michael is shaking all over. Standing about twenty yards away, Graton hasn't missed a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far from Peter, Michael and Jack's building, Graton, in his car, is talking into the microphone of his police radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... My snitch told me the gang hasn't gotten the dope back yet, but they will soon. They made contact with the two guys tonight ... No, no, they don't know I'm tailing them. These jerks are going to fall right into my hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Michael are seated in the living room, which is still an utter wreck. They can't take their eyes off the phone that's between the two of them. They are sitting silently, not moving. Mary is playing in her basket. The PHONE RINGS.   Peter and Michael both jump three feet in the air. Michael picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Who? Goddamn it, where are you?... (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's Jack. He just landed in Newark. He came back early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that. (he grabs the receiver out of Michael's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? What the hell are you doing? (listens to a long explanation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... oh yeah? Well, listen very carefully, Jack. That wonderful, fantastic babe you brought back from Bolivia? The one you're gonna marry tomorrow? Well, you're not going to bring her here!... You are going to say 'goodbye' to her very nicely and put her in a cab back to Bolivia... Why? Because there's another wonderful, fantastic babe waiting for you right here at home ... Who is she? Oh, that's a surprise! You'll see when you get here. But believe me, she's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: out of this world. You're going to be up all night with this babe. She's crazy about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it quick, the punks may be trying to call...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So hurry home, Jack, this little doll can't wait to see you. 'Bye. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a furious temper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goddamn mother fuckin' jerk of an asshole! I swear when he comes through the door I'll kill him!  I'll... The PHONE interrupts.   Michael leaps up and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Listen, tomorrow, Central Park at the fountain near the merry-go-round, five o'clock. Be there, but... They've hung up on the other end.   Michael hangs up and sits down, drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally drained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we can do now is hope our plan works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the cops have our phone bugged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's legal, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graton is speaking into the microphone of his radio. Next to him sits a cop with phone-tapping equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got 'em, Chief. Five o'clock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tomorrow at the fountain near the merry-go-round! I'll arrange for back-up... Hold it, someone's going into their building... We see Jack getting out of a taxi with his luggage and going into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack emerges from the elevator happy as a lark and feeling frisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo, guys! I'm home! I've got presents for you... so where's that wonderful fantastic babe... He enters and sees the state the apartment is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What the hell happened here? He walks into the apartment, shocked and overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter!    Michael! Are you here? He goes into the    living room -- No one'sthere. Into Michael's room.     No one's there. He goes into his own room, where the    destruction is even moreshocking than elsewhere since    nothing has been touchedin there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! My beautiful room! My beautiful, beautiful room! (very angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael!... Peter -- where the hell are you, for Chrissakes? He runs like a madman into Peter's room and stops short on the threshold. Michael and Peter are each holding a handle of the basket as they rock it gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on around here? What happened to this place? What happened to my room? Peter and Michael look him right in the eye, still rocking the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And anyway, what the hell are you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: swinging that thing for? (silence) Answer me for God's sake! (looking in) Oh my God, there's a kid in there! Have you've gone bananas!? There's a Goddamn kid in there! (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I get it. The    'silent' treatment! Okay, if you won't   talk to me, you can talk to my lawyer!    This is grounds for divorce! You're in    big trouble, the both of you. He leaves.   A second later, he comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid to have this place decorated, too, you know. I'm not going to let you get away with this. He leaves; a second later, he comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late to try and talk me out of it. I'm history. I'm gone. I'm outa here. He leaves.   A second later, he comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you one more chance to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calmly) Would it be asking too much of you to shut your big mouth for a few seconds? There is a child here who's trying to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's another thing! I will not have a baby in this house! Babies are not part of our agreement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Michael, please hold me back... or I'll kill him. Michael takes the basket handle from  Peter's hand, place the basket carefully on the bed, and  walks without a wor towards Jack, who he takes by the arm  and steers into th living room. Peter softly shuts the   door behind them an follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael sits Jack down in an armchair.     He speaks with forced calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Jack. Why don't we start at the very beginning. The very day you left for your vacation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, will you please stop talking like Mr. Rogers? It's getting on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his fuse has blown, laughing hysterically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His nerves! Ha. Ha. Ha. His nerves! Michael, his nerves! You wanna talk about nerves! Then just shut up and listen. It so happens we don't want a kid here either, but when someone dumps one on us, we take goddamn care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we take goddam care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't had a decent night's sleep in two weeks. Michael's probably going to lose a $15,000 contract...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter couldn't leave. Jerry almost jumped out the window. It's lucky they even made it to the finals!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, we've got the    narcs on our ass, then there's the    drug gang threatening to carve    us up. Then bottles... bottles...    every three hours, bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And diapers. Have you ever tried to do diapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'La Paz, Bolivia...' He calls from ... 'I'm onto something hot.' He says. 'Did the package get there?' He says. You asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the day they wrecked the apartment, Peter came home and couldn't find Mary. I've never seen him in tears like that bef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off; embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind about that. Look, Jack, you got us into this mess, and you're going to help us get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys talking about? What narcs? What gang? And who's that fucking baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your information, the 'fucking' baby's name is Mary. And if I were you, I'd watch what I said about her... because she just so happens to be your daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it just so happens, we've got a lot better things to do with our lives than wipe a baby's ass, even if she's yours! Peter and Michael exit, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is slicking his hair back with Brylcream. Jack is sitting on the edge of the bathtub, with his arms crossed. He observes Peter silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is lying on the bed and Michael is putting the dope- filled diaper on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is giving a tousled-looking punk hairstyle to Jack, who is looking at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous. I look ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look completely ridiculous -- so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY, wearing a bonnet and coat, is lying on one of the couches, CHIRPING merrily. Next  to her, also in his coat, Michael is just finishing wrapping a brown package which he puts in a plastic bag, along with a book, a baby rattle, and a clean diaper. Peter and Jack, disguised as punks, each with punk hairstyles and wearing black sunglasses, are climbing out the window leading to the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael exits the building. Mary, wrapped in a little woolen blanket, is in his arms. Michael is also carry- ing his plastic bag. Graton, in his car, is speaking into the radio mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, he's coming out alone. I'll follow him. Someone else stay here to keep an eye on the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is lying on the grass near the fountain with Mary on her blanket near him. Graton is nearby, also lying casually on the grass, watching them out of the corner of his eye. Michael glances at his watch, then at the passersby. The punk from the day before walks by with his arm around a girl. He strolls by casually. He spots Michael and their eyes meet. The couple sit down on a bench a few yards away and they begin "making out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael leans over Mary, coochie-coos her and surrepti- tiously takes off her diaper, which he puts down beside him. He puts the clean diaper on her. Graton, nervous and wary,   watches Michael and the passersby. Just then, two    punks (Peter and Jack) come running up to Michael. He    ostensibly takes the brown package out of his plastic   bag and gives it to them. The two punks immediately take off with the package. Graton leaps up, shouts "let's get 'em" and takes off after the punks, followed by about 10 other plainclothes detectives, who'd been hiding all around. Michael quickly gets up,    picks Mary up and discreetly deposits the dope-filled    diaper in a trash can, giving the punk on the bench an    intent look. Then he goes off in the direction of the    cops. The punk calmly goes over to the trash can, takes out the diaper, which he stuffs into his girl friend's purse, and goes off in the opposite direction. The cops have meanwhile arrested Peter and Jack, who put up no resistance whatsoever. Michael now joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Graton, Narcotics. Do you admit you gave these men this package?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I gave it to them, just a moment ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one of the cops) Officer, will you please open this package in front of these witnesses? The cop opens the package: it's a box of chocolate Easter bunnies. Graton is mortified. He crushes all the bunnies -- there's absolutely nothing but chocolate inside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it against the law to give a box of candy to my friends? Peter and Jack take off their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys must think you're pretty smart, don't ya? (suddenly freezes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit! The diaper! Graton starts running like crazy back to the fountain. He rummages like a sick dog all around the spot where Michael had been lying. Suddenly he dashes toward the trash can and dumps out its contents, throwing the garbage around like a lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goddam diaper! What a jerk, what a goddam schmuck I am! Peter, Michael, Jack and the 10 plainclothes detectives watch Graton going bananas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that guy needs a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should try South America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hear it's nice there this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief is standing behind his desk, red-faced with anger, and Graton sheepishly faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's face it... Graton... You've got shit for brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the dope was in the diaper. Can I go on tailing them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I have solid information your three suspects never had anything to do with the dealers or the dope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the dope was in the diaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Case closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the dope was in the diaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me, Graton?   Case closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the d...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the devastated living room Peter, still disguised as a punk, and Michael, both very high, are dancing around in circles with each other and laughing. They are singing a lullaby at the top of their lungs, and har- monizing. Peter is holding Mary close, and Michael, holding a near-empty bottle of liquor, staggers over to him and starts turning around in circles with him. MARY, snuggled up warmly between Peter and Michael, is LAUGHING her head off. In the b.g., in the hall, Jack, also still in his punk getup, is on the phone. He's got a glass in his hand and is a little smashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, hi, it's Jack! Hey, listen, I brought you back a little present from South America. Can I see you right away so I can give it to you? ... Yeah, the sooner the better! I can't wait to let you have it. How about 67th and East River?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A broadly smiling Jack arrives at the riverside. Paul is sitting on a bench. When he sees Jack, he gets up and comes to greet him, smiling and extending his hand. Without warning, Jack suddenly jumps him and  sends him with a forceful shove flying into the water.   Paul lands on his back with a big splash, and comes back  up to the surface totally dumbfounded. Jack leans over   the water and yells at him, like a madman, still a bit  drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was for your 'little' package, and consider yourself lucky I didn't turn you in to the cops! And get one thing into your thick skull: I have never touched dope,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and I never will. You and your shit-dealing, you can go straight to hell, and you can take the money you make from it and stick it up your ass! So long. Jack turns his back on Paul and staggers off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come back! -- how'm I gonna get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room, Michael is sitting in front of the TV. He's not really watching -- he's eavesdropping on Jack's phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very aggravated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Sylvia, you've got to come back. I travel, I can't take care of her... Yeah, but you're her mother... I'm her father -- what makes you so sure I'm the father!? The dates coincide! Big deal! That doesn't prove a thing... But she's still your kid, so do me a favor, get your ass back here immediately and take her off our hands... 'Cause we've got a lot better things to do with our lives than wipe a baby's ass, okay? Sylvia?... Hello! Hello! Sylvia, goddam it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he slams the receiver down like he was hammering a nail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! That bitch hung up on me! Women! I could kill them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you call her back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the number. I got a message to her through her agency, they won't tell me where she is. I don't even know where she was calling from. And you better believe she's not going

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to call back! The PHONE RINGS.   Michael answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?... No, it's Michael... How are you?... Oh, she's doing just fine, she's in great shape. We're taking very good care of her, you have nothing to worry about. 'Bye. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia -- She wanted to know how Mary was doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Jesus Christ, Michael, why didn't you let me talk to her!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would have just hung up on you again. The important thing is she knows Mary's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jerk! You should've said she was terrible, sick as hell! Practically on death's door! (exits, furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a jerk, what a pain in the ass you can be sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with him? The kid's doing really great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is on the phone in his room, which is looking a little more normal again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? Hi, how are you?... Yes, I'm fine. Yes, I'm eating well. Mom, how would you feel if I told you you were a grandma?... SCREAMING coming over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah... A little girl, Mary... SCREAMING coming over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'd love you to see her. In fact, I was gonna bring her down tomorrow... today?... Great, I think there's a flight in three hours. I'll be at your place by two. See you real soon! He hangs up gleefully, rubbing his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Jack are in the kitchen. Michael is making some bottles. Jack is watching him do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have four already made, this'll hold till Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to make sure Mary gets plenty of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If her ass gets red, tell her not to listen to any pediatricians -- they're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.     Full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she should give her a bottle of water instead of the regular bottle. Works like a charm: Her ass will be white as snow in three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottle of water, white as snow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter says her clothes should be washed by hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, by hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And only in soap flakes without any artificial color or scent. And then rinsed three times in very hot water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (docile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rinse three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To put her to sleep we sing in harmony -- it always works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother lives alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo works just as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, as for the nipples, you've got to be very, very, very careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as the hole gets too big she's gotta throw them out -- This is extra, extra, extra-specially important -- 'cause if the hole's too big, the milk comes out too fast and it's bad for her digest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely, but a little in a hurry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get going, I'll miss my plane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is returning from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone home? Michael is in the living room, eating a sandwich, while looking through a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I am!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How 'bout Jack?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: On his way to Miami.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. He's got a lot of nerve! Leaving us with the kid again...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, he took Mary to his mother's, she couldn't wait to see her. He's gonna try to unload her on her till Sylvia gets back. I made her four bott...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (furious) You're kidding! That son-of-a- bitch!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I told him everything he had to know, and I made her four bott...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm telling you, that guy is really starting to get on my nerves!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Goddamn him! He really could have called me!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Are you pissed off 'cause she's gone?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Of course not! What, are you crazy? I'm relieved! Thank God she's out of here!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I made her four bott...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That idiot! He     could at least have told me. (exits,    cursing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe    this... That jackass... That    jerk... There are such things as    phones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four bottles for the goddam trip. There, I finally got it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab slowly pulls up in front of Jack's mother's house. There is a big red convertible filled with four jovial senior citizens. Jack comes out of the cab with the baske and stares at his mother, MARGIE, who's just locking her door. Next to her, holding her luggage is Steve (a man in his sixties). They head toward the trunk of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hits Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he finally made it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what time it is? It's four. You said two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mom, I missed the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but now I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a cruise around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why didn't you say so on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you never would've come. Now let me see her. (she grabs Mary and covers her with kisses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my little strudle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Margie.   We're a little late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye-bye, sweetie love... I'll bring you back presents from all over the world. (to Jack, giving back Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four o'clock. She runs into the car and they pull away.     Everyone waving goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack comes in with the basket; he's in a vile mood. He's got a bottle ready in his hand. Peter, who had been working in his room, rushes to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bringing her back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... she's starving. I gotta heat this bottle up right away. They go into the kitchen together. Peter immediately gets busy; he heats the bottle up quickly while Jack soothes the hungry Mary by carrying her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened? Did you two have a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn cruises...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't she want to take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure she did, but she was just leaving for some stupid cruise around the world. The entire fucking world! With some bimbo boyfriend of her's... and a bunch of retired bozos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apple doesn't fall far from the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. Jack goes to the door. At the door stands a rather distinguished-looking woman, with her hair tied back very properly, a suitcase in her hand. It is MRS. BRETSAWS, who speaks with a British accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. I'm Mathilda Bretsaws, from The Second Mommy agency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very eager, very gracious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I was expecting you. Won't you come in... They disappear into the living room. Jack shuts the door behind him. Michael peeks into the hall, then goes and looks into the living room through the crack in the door. Peter, too, peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be some nanny he found through an agency. Peter shrugs and walks away. Jack comes out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to see Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she wants to see her anyway! He heads toward Peter's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning from the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go into my room, she's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the nanny, Mrs. Bretsaws, she wants to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, damn it, no! You're gonna wake her up! It already took me an hour to sing her to sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but she wants to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll go explain the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding him back with both hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, Peter, please, really, don't go, don't bother, I'll go explain it to her myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no bother, Jack.    I'll be glad to do it. He rushes toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing, to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna bet she's out of here in ten minutes slamming the door behind her? They tiptoe over to the living room door and eavesdrop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... A sleeping child should not be awakened. If you don't know that, then you're not fit to be a nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense, but still calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that I wanted the child to be awakened, sir. I only asked to see her. If I'm going to be taking care of the child on a round-the-clock basis, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Round-the-clock'? Whaddya mean 'round the clock'? Are you intending to sleep here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely, sir. A second mommy is a second mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are you going to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I expect you to show me to my quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know where Jack intends to stick you... That's his problem... Maybe in his room... But I'm warning you, Mrs. Brestshow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bretsaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three of us sharing this place and we're all real studs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the door, Jack rolls his eyes, Michael empathizes with him. They head back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And as for screwing, I have all I need at home, thank you very much. With a few days off every month, I'm sure I'll be fine. The only thing I'm interested in is the care of the child and I can tell she needs some.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?   How do you figure that?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Shouldn't I be discussing all this with the father?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, listen, Mrs. Fretsaw, umm... Brainsore...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Bretsaws, Mrs. Bretsaws.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right... Bratsnot, lemme tell you something. With a child you always know who the mother is, but the father -- that's another kettle of fish. So don't give me that bullshit, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Very well. I won't discuss it any further with you. Will you please show me where the kitchen and the bathroom are?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: So I can make you a list of the things we need.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, make you a list? -- Don't you do the shopping yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: No shopping or laundry or housekeeping. I am a professional nanny.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We have plenty of everything.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Do you have a sufficient amount of fruit and vegetables for the child?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She only eats milk and cereal.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: That's not enough, sir. From the age of three months children should be started on a normal, varied diet.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh that's bullshit. You don't feed a baby like an adult.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: (mockingly) Oh, really? And how would you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I've read plenty of books. The diet recommended by those quack pediatricians today is way too rich. I'm in favor of natural methods, Mrs. Breathmint.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Bretsaws, Mrs. Bretsaws.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: For instance, if a child is having trouble getting to sleep, what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Depends, if it was a continuing problem, I might recommend a mild sedative...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (exploding, triumphantly) I knew you'd say something like that, you jerk!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: Fine. Anything you     say, sir. Let me just remind    you that I have my diploma and that    medicine is a serious matter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you know the song that goes 'Medicine's a whore and the pharmacist is her pimp'?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRETSAWS
dialogues.text: No, I don't. We must listen to different music. Personally I'm very fond of opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Breakballs, if you don't get out of here right this minute I'm gonna punch you in the nose! This is my home, now get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Bretsaws. I am blessed with infinite patience when it comes to children, sir, but I'm not qualified to deal with lunatics. Goodbye and good luck! Mrs. Bretsaws grabs her suitcase and exits, dignified and stiff as a broom, slamming the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Jack are sitting at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you? Ten minutes to the second!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, listen, you guys... I've tried everything and nothing's working: my mother's off on a cruise; Mrs. Razzolini won't speak to us ever since the whole business with the cops -- we don't want to involve any of our girlfriends; Sylvia's taking it easy in Europe and there's no way she's gonna come back now that Michael went and told her everything's just fine and dandy. Peter did a terrific job getting rid of Mrs. Bretsaws, and all that's left are the daycare centers, but Peter's positive they're a breeding pit for A.I.D.S. So you tell me: What are we suppose to do? You want me to split with the kid? Or dump her in an orphanage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to play the violin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Look,  her mother'll be back in less  than five months. Let's not waste  a shitload of time looking for a  solution for such a short time.   Let's get organized.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you mean, organized?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, you'll have to ask to fly the New York-Washington shuttle for five months, on account of serious personal problems.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What? Never! I'd rather be a subway conductor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (barking) Then dump her in an orphanage, 'cause there's no way we're gonna take care of her all by ourselves anymore!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Come on, stop arguing, you two! Jack, you're going to have to ask to do the New York-Washington shu...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (stubborn, yelling) No!   Never.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (unruffled) That way, you can do the 6-10 A.M. shift. That amounts to two bottles and two diaper changes. You do the shopping when you get home in the evening and that's all. Peter, you'll take the 6-10 P.M. shift. That's two bottles and two diaper changes, her bath and her laundry. Since I work at home I'll take the longest shift from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. I'll take her to the park for an hour, but that's it. No shopping, no cooking, no cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What if she gets up at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose shift is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I thought you might do it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a    chance! I'm not doing the night    shift. I absolutely refuse. I have    too much work to catch up on for    the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, needless to say I refuse, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you selfish bastards! My shift is eight hours in a row. No way I'm gonna do nights too. After 6 P.M. she can scream all she wants, I don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Jack, you're a real slime ball! We give you the easiest shift: the morning. She's always in great shape in the morning, isn't she? We've got to work like crazy to save our jobs and you have the nerve to refuse nights. Goddamit, she's your daughter. Are you that horny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely pissed off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, horny yourself! I don't give a shit. I don't need you guys. I'll find some other way to do it. And I won't take the New York-Washington shuttle! He exits, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is coming out of   an office that says "EXECUTIVE OFFICES." He is grim    and sullen-looking. He runs into his friend Paul, who   jumps three feet away to avoid a potential mishap with   Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jack, something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who hadn't noticed him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi... Nah, nothing's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing in the boss's office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was asking to do the New York- Washington shuttle for a few months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and he said 'no,' huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, he said 'yes.' Paul backs up against the wall, protecting his face with his arms. Jack leaves, disgusted. Paul watches him go, totally confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is sitting on his bed, wearing a dressing gown. He's got a sleeping Mary in his arms. The basket is on the floor beside the bed. Jack attempts to put Mary back in her basket but she shudders and he immediately sits back down again and doesn't move. Mary falls back asleep. Jack looks at her skin, her hands. Very gently, he kisses her forehead. Mary smiles in her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is working at his drafting table.      Jack rushe in, wearing his uniform, ready to go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm off. She's well fed and she's sleeping now. We hear MARY CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, she's crying.      I'll go pick her up... Peter passes him in the corridor.      He, too, is ready go out to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her cry, she's just trying to get to sleep, she'll stop in a couple of minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she needs to burp -- I've gotta rock her for a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, the more you pick her up, the longer it'll take her to get to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice -- now why don't you just shove it? I know you let her scream for hours but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a state of shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never let her scream for hours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd resort to any theory to not take care of her. Just because you've read some books...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe what he just said to me... I read those books bec...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your shift, anyway. Piss off, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, guys, cool it! It's my shift now. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll rock her for a few minutes... (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and then I'll put her right to bed. So off to work, both of you. He pushes them both out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's noon, the sun is   shining brightly. Michael is diapering Mary on her   changing table. She's naked. He tickles her, bites   her toes, neck and ears; she bursts out laughing.    Michael is totally gaga over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coochie, coochie, coo... woo, woo, woo... bippity, boppity boo... Peter comes rushing into the apartment and runs toward his room. He stops short in the corridor -- he hears Mary's laughter and Michael's coochie-coo's. Noiselessly he tiptoes over to the living room door and listens, troubled. Then he walks away and shouts, as though he were just coming out of his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Michael, I just came back to get a file I forgot... Michael stops his baby-talk immediately, as though sud- denly paralyzed, embarrassed, guilty. Peter enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not moving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll be going now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not moving either)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... They're both uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not budging an inch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Peter exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the bathroom. He's carrying Mary, who's naked and wrapped in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter carefully locks the door behind him. He removes Mary's towel and sits her in her little tub, filled with warm water. Mary quivers as she comes in contact with the water. Peter kneels down and very gently pours glasses of water on her shoulders and head. The water streams down her face. She blinks and laughs. Peter whispers lovingly to her in a barely audible, very low voice. Mary stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Peter is wearing a different suit and Mary is almost one-year-old, with a lot more hair on her head, and able to sit up a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it is dark, we can distinguish in Jack's bed a rather bulky shape, which is moving around under the comforter and doesn't exactly seem to be sleeping... Suddenly, from the direction of    the living room, we ca hear MARY CRYING. Jack emerges     from under the comfort and switches on the light: he     has a female guest in his bed, a pretty BRUNETTE this    time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, she's crying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing. I'll be right back. He gets up, slips on a bathrobe and goes out of the bedroom, carefully closing the door behind him. He goes into the living room, picks Mary up, and showers her with kisses. Mary stops crying immediately and lays her head on Jack's shoulder, sucking her thumb. Jack rocks her for a moment then puts her back to bed. Mary instantly starts crying again. Jack very quickly picks her up again and kisses her. Mary is delighted by his tenderness. Jack puts her back to bed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary cries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It' beddy-bye time now, honey, beddy-bye, don't cry, sweetheart... Mary keeps crying, Jack picks her up again. Peter and Michael in their pajamas, their faces swollen with sleep, enter the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a soft voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, every time I try to put her back to bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's thirsty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, her back teeth must be starting to bother her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've bought some stuff for her gums. He rubs some of the medication on Mary's gums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and put her back to bed; we'll sing. Jack puts Mary back to bed. Michael, as a routine, sings a major chord, giving each of them their notes. They start singing a lullabye in three-part harmony, as they lean over the crib. Mary is in seventh heaven. She looks up at them, she stops crying, she sucks her thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brunette is listening to the male chorus, totally amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's totally whacko. She gets up, slips on a T-shirt, and exits the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops at the door to the living room and contemplates the three men who are singing earnestly around the crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice) Hey, choir boys, you gonna keep it up all night? Peter and Michael stare at her, scandalized. Jack gestures wildly to her to shut up and go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! There's a baby in there! I'm sorry... She goes back to Jack's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hissing) Who the hell's that broad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth, will you? I'm in love with that young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't she speak softly like everyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting angry) Listen, at night I'm in charge. So get off my back, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Will you quit fighting all the time? She just fell asleep, for Chrissake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Michael, go to hell! I'm sick and tired of your little 'Father Knows Best' number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're right, I'm fed up with it, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terribly upset) Okay, that's it. Into the kitchen. He exits, furious. Peter and Jack follow after him. Fuming, they file one after the other down the corridor past the stunned Brunette in her T-shirt who was waiting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for Jack by the door to his room. The three guys close the kitchen door and start yelling at each other. They all talk at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had it with you assholes! I won't be the buffer between you two anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to get up, I know what I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind getting up, that's not the point...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a punching bag!   You assholes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can't bring a girl back here anymore, just say so. And I'm gone. I'm outta here. With Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can bring whoever you want as long as they speak softly like everyone else!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I know: I can't goddamn wait till Sylvia gets back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can say that again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And again, and again, and again... Meanwhile, the Brunette has put her clothes back on and gathered up her belongings. Now she enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb you guys, but I'm splitting. I didn't come here to be a bedwarmer. 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running after her) No! Wait, please don't go... it's all over now, I'm coming back to bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the front door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very nice, but I don't feel like it anymore now. Some other time, okay? 'Bye. She kisses him goodbye and leaves. Jack is very depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, Michael and Jack have guests over for dinner. CLASSICAL MUSIC, a very fancy table, candles: they're at the tail-end of the dinner, before dessert. Everyone is very fashionably dressed. Natalie is sitting between Peter and Carl. Jay and Jerry, Peter's partners, are also there with their wives. Michael and Sophia are having a vehement discussion as usual, Jack is between two gorgeous models: CHRISTIE and CAROLINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen the latest bi-annual at the Whitney? Incredible! Have you seen it, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't had the time lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... working hard on the competition, are you? You may as well throw in the T-square, old friend, you haven't got a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat harshly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only wish he was working hard on the competition, but unfortunately, that's not the case...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What's he doing then? He's always so busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's working hard on women! Some people have to work really hard to get anything! Natalie bursts out laughing. Peter's about to respond, but stops himself suddenly. In the b.g., a BABY can be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: heard CRYING. Peter, Jack, and Michael exchange glances.    Jack rushes out. The guests haven't heard anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Natalie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always have to bring Carl along with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon -- I love him! Only, I'd like to see you alone for once, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's  extremely talented -- in fact,  I hate to tell you this, but I  think he and his group are gonna  win the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll see about that. Jack returns to the table.   Peter's eyes follow him nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone, to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you give her something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunkenly) Oh, cut it out! No more for me! I've had eight glasses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low tone, to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried, but she doesn't want anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do so want some, but if I have anymore I'll pass out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save room for dessert -- it's a three-tiered cake from Balducci's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!   Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greedily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love three-tiered cakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's it made of? In the b.g., the BABY starts CRYING again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
