dialogues.text: Umm, it's made with whipped cream and loads of nipples on top -- I mean, loads of... raspberries ... I'll be right back... Peter rushes out of the room. Michael and Jack exchange glances. The CRYING CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that's not art? Are you really saying that's not art? Well, then, you explain what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's... art. I'll be right back. He gets up and goes out.    Jack watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, tell me about those exotic places, what is Caracas like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mind elsewhere)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually... uh, lately I've been to Washington a lot... and uh... I'll be right back. He gets up and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men are talking. Jack is holding Mary, whose eyes are swollen with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and put her back to bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, she'll scream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she's cutting a tooth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the living room, Christie's voice can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo! What are you guys doing in there? It's fucking boring without you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit -- the guests...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two go... I'm staying with her. It can't be worse than listening to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair -- let's take Mary out there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the hell with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men enter the living room; Jack is carrying Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell did that come from? Wow! Is it a boy or a girl? Who does it belong to? So you've got a kid now? Incredible! Does that come from Balducci's? No kidding, whose baby is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like you to meet my daughter, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter... your daughter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding! Congratulations! She's adorable! She looks just like you... Oh, what a cute little girl! Overwhelmed by all the people, MARY bursts out CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking her back and forth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, Mary, don't cry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's too much noise. He shuts the MUSIC OFF.   MARY keeps on SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to everyone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's teething, that's why she's cranky. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her to me, I'll try and calm her down. Peter takes MARY on his lap.    The SCREAMING CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very tense) Don't sit down -- it'll get worse. You have to walk around. Peter gets up and walks around.      Jack and Michael, standing, watch him walk. MARY SCREAMS even LOUDER as Peter walks back and forth in the room with her. The guests watch in uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you had this kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few months...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat sharply) Who's her mother, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in Europe, she'll be back in a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she always cry like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's only because she's teething, she's usually very sweet... The guests remain silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to break the silence) You'd never think something so small could make a noise so big. MARY'S CRYING fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you just put her back to bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right -- she's just throwing a temper tantrum, put her to bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We already tried...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her teeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) Do you have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but they're grown up now, thank God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jay) And do you have kids, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said... and do you have kids, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we both have careers. The guests remain silent, MARY CONTINUES to CRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, do you think we'll get to taste that three-tiered cake tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Natalie, sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing, nothing -- I was just trying to liven up the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: conversation...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: Gosh, my ears are ringing, I can't hear anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I must say, a crying kid is kind of hard to take...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (loudly) We were just saying that this baby's conversation is actually rather limited... and a touch annoying. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, she's not the only one with a limited conversation. At least she has an excuse, she's a baby! What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I frankly don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I mean, I've been listening to your pompous drivel about the latest trends for the last two hours, and frankly, it's a crock of horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Come on, Peter, be nice...

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Listen, go put the baby to bed and you guys cool it, will you?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm used to it. Peter's always been a sore loser.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (totally out of control) You motherfucker, get out of here! Get out of my house right now or I'll kick the shit out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of you! You snobbish scum- sucking snake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Peter. Give her to me, I'll put her to bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beside himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll go. (to all the guests)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can all go fuck yourselves! Go back to your asinine conversations! He exits with Mary.    Jack, embarrassed, follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to recover)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... umm... How 'bout if I get the cake now, okay? He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It seems our beloved hosts are going to be busy playing mother for a while, so if you'll excuse me, I'll just slip away... (to Natalie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Natalie, may I invite you to spend the rest of the evening in a more hospitable place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladly. (to the guests)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry and his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he out of his mind or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was absolutely obnoxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunk, getting up and tottering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Caroline, I think we should

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: go, too. I don't feel so good... I think I'm gonna barf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running to help her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, no! Hold it back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) I wanna go home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we're going... (to the others) Sorry... say goodbye to Jack for us... They exit.   Christie is hanging on to Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) Look, there's no point in our staying any longer. I think it's best we leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) Tell Peter if was a wonderful party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sad) Okay... 'Bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you drop me off near Soho by any chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks! (to Jerry and his Wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye... Say goodbye to them for me... Sophia, Jay and his Wife exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we might as well go, too. I think the evening's over. She gets up, so does Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, very playful, comes back in carrying an enormous three-tiered cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta-da! Will you look at this? Is this a cake or what? Can someone make a little room on the table so I can... Are you guys leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the atmosphere wasn't exactly festive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the cake, Mike... It looks great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, never mind, don't worry... Good night... Jerry and his Wife exit. Michael is left standing there with his cake. Jack comes in, full of beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's asleep at last! We sang in har... Hey, where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone. Can you make a little room for me on the table to put the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they're all gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, all of 'em, hey, can you make a little room for me to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going back out, furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter! Peter, goddamit, get out here! Peter comes back in with Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit, they're all jerks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, could you make a little room for me on the table so I can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because of the kid.     They can't stand kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand kids either but that's not a reason to leave! Dipshits, they're all a bunch of dipshits, every one of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck it -- I'm sitting down. He sits down on a chair with the cake on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did    you hear Natalie: 'She's throwing    a temper tantrum, just put her    to bed.' What a pain-in- the-ass    that broad is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed off) Hey, you're the pain-in-the-ass! First you dump a baby on us, then you scare everyone away from the party, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I scared    everyone aw... Just cut the    crap, will you? My whole life is    diapers, shuttles and bottles.     I do the graveyard shift, I'm the    one who never gets any sleep.     I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, we all have two full-time jobs! That's for sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about me? I'm a prisoner in this house all day long, forget about chasing ass, I haven't gotten laid in six months. When the hell is your friggin' Sylvia gonna come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been gone for six months and four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's not back by the end of next week, I'm kicking her kid out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better give your goddam Sylvia hell for this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, she's gonna get it but good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can tell her we have a lot better things to do with our lives than wipe a baby's ass, goddamn it! He exits. So does Jack. Michael is buried under the three-tiered cake, unable to see around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you guys want some cake? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her crib Mary is sleeping.   She's beautiful, she looks happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in her playpen, playing with a SQUEAKY rubber giraffe. The DOORBELL RINGS. Peter opens it: standing there before him is a very, very, young, gorgeous girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting with joy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... I'm Sylvia, Mary's mother. I've come to get her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely dazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you... Wait, I'll go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: get Jack... He stands there, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Mary doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he were dreaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, fine, she's doing great... She's getting her back teeth in lately, it's been a bit rough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sure, she's in there... They both enter the living room. Mary stares at Sylvia. When she spots Mary, Sylvia suddenly breaks down in tears Peter is dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe how much she's grown! Recovering, wiping away her tears, she walks over to the playpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary, hello my darling... She picks her up, hugs her tightly, showers kisses on her. MARY LAUGHS. Sylvia starts crying again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How beautiful she is... Her hair has grown... Look how much she changed, I missed it all. I missed her so much! Peter, in a kind of daze, stares at Sylvia. Without looking at Peter, she dries her eyes and tries to stop crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to make life difficult for Jack but I never thought I'd miss her so much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in a fog) Oh, yeah... make life difficult for Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Jack here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping out of it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yeah, I'll go get him... He exits like a sleepwalker and goes straight into Michael's room. The latter is asleep. Peter sits down on the edge of Michael's bed and gently shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, Michael... Sylvia's here. Michael wakes up and looks at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's giving Mary her bottle, Jack is carefully putting all her stuff into a bag -- bottles, nipples, cereals, etc. In the doorway Sylvia, with reddened eyes, silently watches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, the five bottles, the little bottles for water, the strainer for her cereal... (to Sylvia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Do you have a blender?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blender?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For bananas and carrots and stuff. It's time for her to start eating them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't have a blender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you can have ours. He stuffs the blender into the bag. Mary has now finished her bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Do you want me to take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have to burp her first. With dexterity, he places Mary face down on his shoulder and walks around in the kitchen, patting her on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sylvia) Here, could you give these to Michael so he can pack them with the clothes? He hands two bibs to Sylvia. Sylvia walks through the apartment, and stops in front of Michael's room, where she looks strangely at the changing table with its mattress, its pretty sheet, and the baby's toilet articles. Sylvia enters the living room. Michael has spread all of Mary's clothes, neatly folded and ironed on the couch. He is packing them in a big bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are the bibs. Jack told me to give them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the bibs) Thanks... I put the woolen things on the bottom and the diapers and lighter things on top, because you'll need those first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her mind is elsewhere)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... Michael bustles about. Sylvia's gaze comes to rest on the crib which stands imposingly in the middle of the living room. Music boxes, little booties and stuffed animals are hanging from the bars, and a pretty white tulle frames the crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to come back and get the crib later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi is there. Behind the    wheel the driver sits waiting. Sylvia is sitting    in the back, on the side nearest the sidewalk, and on   her lap is Mary, whom she's gently fondling. On the sidewalk, beside the   open trunk of the cab, are all Mary's belongings:    some bags, the playpen, a stroller, the baby bathtub,   the changing table, etc. Peter is attempting to pack it all in the trunk.    Micha is handing the things to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the playpen first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally tense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then where are you gonna put the tub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me the playpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need some help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no thanks... I'd rather do it myself... Jack is standing beside the back door of the cab, leaning over toward Sylvia, who is holding Mary. He is trying unsuccessfully to sound angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really screwed us over but good -- you know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Our lives have been out of control for the past six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I bet... Actually, that was kind of the point... But I'm the one who really got screwed... She starts to cry again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, c'mon... you're taking her back now, it's great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping her eyes) Yeah, it's great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you have enough money?     Can you manage all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... I'm not loaded, but it's okay -- I'm working, I've got modeling jobs lined up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's the last thing I need. I've got my work. And now I've got her. She rubs noses with Mary. Peter and Michael approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, we fit it all in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then... well, 'bye... The three men are lined up on the sidewalk. Mary stares at them, looking a little lost. They wave their hands and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Mary! MARY LAUGHS and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a big, sad smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, thanks again -- 'Bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye! The CAR STARTS up, pulls away, and disappears FROM VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) Well, that's that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... That's that. They head back to their apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit -- I forgot to explain about the cereal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll figure it out by herself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she'll manage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's back to the good life for us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping late! Different women every night! I can't wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about the New York-Washington shuttle! I'm off to Caracas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm gonna be able to get back to work, so Carl better watch it -- I'm gonna slaughter that son-of-a-bitch! First with this goddam competition... and then with Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've got six months' worth of sex to catch up on with Cathy, Nora, Frances, Susan, Barbra... They have entered the elevator. The doors close. They come out of the elevator, in front of their apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Christie, Paula, Sheila, Lisa, Kimberly, Rhonda, Rebecca, Louisa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not necessarily in that order! They enter the apartment and Peter walks on something that lets out a TERRIBLE SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she forgot her squeaky giraffe. He picks it up and throws it onto an armchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack takes a running jump and does a cannonball into the pool of a luxury hotel somewhere in the world. He splashes two girls who find it very funny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, with a bouquet of flowers, runs like mad down a street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Sophia are having a big discussion about contemporary art in the midst of a sophisticated crowd at an opening. Michael is vehement, gesturing wildly, and so is Sophia. They're both talking at once, not listening to each other, and enjoying it immensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, all out of breath, comes rushing into the office where Natalie works. She is very surprised. He puts the flowers down on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are for you... I'm not supposed to leave the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think I'm in the bathroom. So I can't stay. 'Bye. He dashes back out.   Natalie cracks up, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is running on the tarmac; he quickly mounts the stairs to his plane as he waves a heartrending goodbye to a young woman he's left behind in the airport. At the top step, he bumps into another young woman: it's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: love at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael is in bed. It's noon, the sun's shining brightly, and a BLONDE is asleep beside him. Michael is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter? Yeah? What? Yow-ee! Hooray! Terrific! That's fantastic! I'll call Jack -- We're gonna celebrate tonight! He hangs up.   The Blonde is now awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won!    They won!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter.     He won the competition!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!     Who's Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the apartment with Natalie. A bunch of crepe paper streamers are hanging in the hall, as well as posters with various things written on them:

dialogues.speaker: HURRAY
dialogues.text: Jack comes running in with a bottle of champagne, he POPS the CORK. Jack hugs Peter tightly as Michael comes in with glasses and tries to catch the champagne that's flowing all over. They all shout and go bananas celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter has his arm around Natalie's waist. She's a little drunk. He kisses her and leads her into his room, clos- ing the door behind him. Michael and Jack, who were spying on them, tiptoe over to the door. They are silently exulting over Peter's second victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael enters a fancy building on 5th Avenue.   He's carrying a big portfolio and is full of beans. In the lobby, he pushes the button for the elevator and looks around absentmindedly. His gaze suddenly freezes on something. By the guard's desk he notices a stroller. Inside, look- ing pretty bored, is MARY. Michael is overwhelmed. He walks toward Mary and through the sea of people -- they exchange an intense look. He looks around and suddenly sees Sylvia and two men deep in discussion coming out of an elevator. Michael, startled, runs and hides behind one of the elevators, staring out wide-eyed. Sylvia is dressed in a very chic, tight black suit, with a veiled little black hat and spiked heels. One of the men is carrying a bunch of cameras. They walk out toward the front door, and Sylvia suddenly stops. She seems to have forgotten something. She kisses them goodbye and heads toward the elevator. Once she's out of their sight, she turns and waits for them to leave. When they're gone for sure, she rushes toward Mary and showers her with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, my angel... Are you okay, honey? Mommy's finished now, you've been a very, very good girl. (to Guard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot for looking after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she's been great! She wheels the stroller over to the door and quickly takes off her high heels, and her hat, and stuffs them into a big bag. She takes out a pair of old shoes and a comfortable jacket, and slips them on. She removes the pins from her hair -- she looks like her normal self again. She leaves, pushing the stroller out the door. Michael stands frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in the corridor of a large modern hotel somewhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the world. He is full of energy and playful excite- ment. He's with a few of his colleagues, both men and women. They say good night to each other. Everyone goes into his or her own room. Jack's the last one, he goes into his room alone. His smile drops. For a moment he stands there just looking. He sits down on the bed: on the pillow is a little chocolate Santa Claus with a card that reads "Merry Christmas. The Marriott Hotels." Jack contemplates it forlornly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Sophia, both in kimonos, are sitting in front of the last bits of an elegant midnight supper, in Michael's room. The bed in unmade. Sophia, a glass of champagne in her hand, is yakking away nonstop, like a real motor-mouth. Michael, silent, is doodling on a paper napkin. His pen is making little squares and circles; the circles come together and start looking like a baby lying in a crib. Sophia is absorbed in her monologue. Suddenly Michael realizes what he has drawn. He crumples the napkin and throws it in the wastebasket. Sophia hasn't noticed anything. Michael is bored stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter comes home with Natalie.   They take off their coats. They look tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a bad mood)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my feet are killing me! She takes off her shoes and collapses in the armchair in the hall. There is a LOUD SQUEAKING noise. She reaches underneath her and brings out a rubber giraffe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? Oh, it's a giraffe... (tosses it away and walks off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh, by the way, have you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: heard anything about that kid, you know, the one you had here for a while? Peter stares at the giraffe, horrified. He feels the tears coming to his eyes. Grabbing the giraffe, he hurls it with all his might against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's in his plane, at the controls, waiting for takeoff. He's daydreaming. His CO-PILOT comes in and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda you mean, what's the matter with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?   No.   I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Jack! Didn't you see who we've got on board today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I did, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning around to look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's the Rockettes, so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're just sitting there like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddaya mean, sitting there? I happen to be getting ready to fly this airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, alone in his room, with his back to us, is facing his full-length mirror. He's looking at himself, with one fist on his hip and the other hand clutching a half-empty bottle of scotch. He observes himself and slowly turns around -- we can now see him in profile. His hair is disheveled, he's unshaven, and he's put a pillow underneath his sweater. He's pregnant. He takes a big swig of scotch. The DOORBELL RINGS. Jack walks away from the mirror. He staggers dead drunk. But dignified, pregnant. Jack opens the door. Standing there is Graton holding a stuffed animal, a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of it) Hi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a total fog) Wait... uh, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who was tailing you... Remember, in the park...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, the park... the diaper and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, the diaper... But don't worry. This isn't an investigation, I left the force four months ago, and anyway, they've arrested the whole gang since then... I just wanted to ask you something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you noticed? I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (neutrally) Oh yeah, I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, shall we go for a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graton and Jack are sitting on a bench beside the East River. Jack, still pregnant, has brought along his bottle of scotch, and he takes a swig from it occasion- ally. Graton has brought along his rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I have to know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you like to be pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh sure... maybe... no... I dunno... Look, there's been something bothering me for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, if I was God, and I could create the world all over again, here's what I would do: I would create Adam from Eve's rib, not the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having trouble following)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an interesting idea... Actually, I just wanted to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least that way things would have been clearer to begin with, y'see. They wouldn't have made us believe that somebody could come out of our rib, y'know? 'Cause nothing ever comes out of our rib, y'know? Ever. Only out of our prick, and even then ... Everything still has to be done after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very unsure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we men know how to make is planes, buildings, cars, and all that stuff... It's useful, mind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's driving me crazy! This thing keeps going around and around in my head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know what, it's not even like they wanted us to believe it -- it might have been us who wanted to believe it... But let's face it, nobody comes out of our rib...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dives right in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the dope in the diaper, yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, that's hard to take, goddam it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it in the diaper, or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dope?   It was in the diaper, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks a lot. I feel so much better now. Here, this is a rabbit for your baby. (shakes both Jack's hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again, 'bye, I'm so happy. Graton goes off, floating on cloud nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching out toward him with the rabbit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait -- the baby's gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Michael, slumped in their chairs, are having breakfast. It's a gray day. It's POURING out. Peter, bending over a bowl of steaming water, with a towel over his head, is inhaling the steam. When he looks up to speak, we see his swollen tear-streaked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely, in fact, too playful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, San Francisco!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to the Pacific for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more playful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back the day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emerging from the bowl, congested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be id a foul bood -- jet lag really wipes out you dow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: you didd't used to give a shit before, but dow it docks you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very hostile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his head back over the bowl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would I dow? 'Before,' that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on edge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't knock me out at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any jam left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eatig here todight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playful again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm going to the movies tonight with, uh... damn, I can't remember her name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'mean the Japanese one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly very weary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's from Finland. Oh damn it. What the hell's her name? They've got such weird names... Magdalena... no, Marianna... no ... oh, I can't remember -- anyway it's Ma-something or other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary? A sudden, weighty silence ensues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fuckig cold! I look like I'b cryig all the tibe but I'b dot -- it's just this dab cold. He gets up and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, holding a bouquet of flowers and Graton's rabbit, rings the doorbell of an apartment. On the door a card reads "SYLVIA AND MARY." A chubby YOUNG MAN with thick glasses opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.   Is Sylvia in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she'll be back in a couple of hours -- around midnight, she said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna come in and wait for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows the Young Man in Sylvia's studio. It's very messy. On the table there's a big heap of books and papers. Mary, sitting on the floor, is wearing a diaper and a sweater, but her legs are bare. She's playing with an empty pack of cigarettes. She looks at Jack with a serious, unruffled expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia doing okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I'm a med student. I'm just babysitting. I only met her a couple hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see... Silence. The Young Man sits down at the table and immerses himself in his books. Mary doesn't look up from her pack of cigarettes anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, on second thought, I don't think I'll wait for her. Just give her this when she gets back, okay? And this is for the baby. Jack hands the bouquet and the rabbit to the Young Man, who plops them down on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, no problem. He immerses himself again in his books. Jack heads toward the door, then turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't the baby be in bed by now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I don't know... When I put her to bed she cries so I just let her stay up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have any tights to put on her legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tights?... Well, it's pretty hot in here anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets out of there in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in his pilot's uniform, is sitting on the living room couch. Michael is standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to call them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've got to let them know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going anywhere anymore, I've had it with traveling. I quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I'll call you a cab, you've still got time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you call anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the plane's s'posed to take off in half an hour -- They won't have time to replace you. This is serious -- you'll lose your job and you won't be able to pay your share of the apartment anymore... you... Jack takes off his pilot's jacket and throws it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be a dishwasher, I'll live in a flophouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going, I told you; I'm not going ever again. I'm sick and tired of traveling, sick and tired of broads. They all have the same asses and I can't seem to love them anyway. I can't take another hotel room, and swimming pools and trendy restaurants! I want to know

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what my life's all about. Do you know what your life's about, Michael? Michael has no answer to these questions.     He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, wearing an apron and holding a wooden spoon, goes into Jack's room. The latter, lying on his bed, is smoking and staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I made us a good dinner. I bought some filet mignon and Haagen-Dazs butter pecan. When Peter comes back he'll cheer you up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been here all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has?    I didn't hear him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Michael heads towards Peter's room.    Jack feebly gets up and follows him. Michael knocks on the door.     No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter!    Dinner's ready! Still no answer. Michael opens the door:      Peter's lyi face-down on his bed. He's holding the rubber giraffe and sobbing. Michael and Jack, dismayed, stare at him. Peter hides his face in his arm. Jack and Michael go to the kitchen and sit down to their steaks, totally depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. A bare-chested Michael, in jeans, drags himself over to the front door and opens it. There stands Sylvia with Mary in her stroller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia is a disheveled mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Jack here? 'Cause I'm a mess. I can't handle it, I'm all alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting towards Jack's room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!   Jack, c'mere for Chrissake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause my place is tiny, y'know, and my schedule's insane -- and I just finished four days of posing and we ended up every day at... Jack, bare-chested, comes in pulling on his jeans. He stops short at the front door. Sylvia is about to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Yeah, y'see, Jack, I just did four days of posing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every day we finished at three in the morning and since Mary always gets up around 5:30...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can imagine how much sleep I've gotten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, of course, 'cause after the 5:30 bottle it starts all over again around nine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And by the time I change her and play with her a little, it's already eight o'clock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then that's it -- you get only an hour of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the babysitters till three A.M. -- all my money is sucked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: down the tubes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus they don't put the kids to bed, they let them lie around half-naked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so the flowers and the rabbit were from you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have strangled that guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it, I can't cope anymore. My parents and I don't talk to each other and anyway they live in Texas, and the baby needs to get out to the park...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell me about it! Finding time to take her to the park every day is a real bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have to work, I need the money to survive and anyway I love my job... A distraught Peter, bare-chested and in jeans, comes running in from his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But to work I've gotta have a babysitter, and to have a babysitter I need to work, so I run around all day... (she sobs) ... and I'm not sure I'm taking good care of her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you're taking good care of her -- we know what it's like, don't cry, she looks great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) It's just 'cause I haven't slept in four nights -- she must be teething or something, I don't know but I can't manage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it's nothing, she's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cutting a tooth -- you just have to put some stuff on her gums...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulled the same thing on us. We lost all our friends in one night -- on account of one tooth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just look    at my face! Nobody's going    to want me to model for them    with the way my face looks...    And what'll happen to me if they    don't want me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're beautiful -- At your age all you need is a good night's sleep and you'll look like new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, a good night's sleep -- but when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you leave the baby with us for a few days, till you recuperate... I mean, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're old pros -- it's not a big deal for us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing her nose, wiping her eyes) Really? I can leave her with you for a little while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Leave her with us. Come back whenever you want. Get some rest. Sylvia, between two sobs, picks up a big bag beside her on the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought a couple of things for her, just for a few days... Michael eagerly takes the bag from her.    It's followed a second, and then a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Mary in his arms) Is she hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's time for her bottle -- it's all ready in the bag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go heat up some water right away. Would you like a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, thanks... Peter, carrying Mary towards the kitchen, is followed by Jack and Michael with the bags. Sylvia blows her nose and walks around aimlessly in the hall. In the kitchen the three men bustle about with the bags, the bottle, the saucepan... They've swallowed all their pride and are kissing Mary all over, on her neck, her hands, her tummy. They're deliriously happy. Michael takes some sheets out of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go make up her bed! He exits, and, once in the corridor, prances around, leaping and dancing... He gets to the living room and goes over to the crib: suddenly, he recoils and freezes, a fearful expression on his face. Then he turns and races back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (floored) Hey, you guys -- come and see, come and see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come see, I said. Jack and Peter nervously follow Michael into the living room. They stop short in front of the crib: There is Sylvia, curled up in a fetal position, sucking her thumb and sleeping like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor thing, she's really wiped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll need two or three months to recover, at least... Maybe more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could set up a room for her here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room for her and a room for Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we could have four shifts instead of three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don't think she'll agree. She's got her own life to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she probably wouldn't want to move here. She'd think we'd jump on her any chance we could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we'd make a rule, she'd just be 'one of the guys!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll never want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very awake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'll take the ten A.M. to three P.M. shift... And I'll take every other night... plus the walk in the park in the afternoon before I go to work... and we split the rent equally... and I'll just be 'one of the guys'... deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling broadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal. Mary    suddenly comes in from the kitchen, walking unste ily    but determinedly. She's dragging Graton's rabbit b its    ear. She looks at the four of them and laughs her head    off. FREEZE FRAME.
